    2500       16208 :     PG_RETURN_BOOL(result);
    2501             : }
    2502             : 
    2503             : static int
    2504     6446580 : cmp_numerics(Numeric num1, Numeric num2)
    2505             : {
    2506             :     int         result;
    2507             : 
    2508             :     /*
    2509             :      * We consider all NANs to be equal and larger than any non-NAN (including
    2510             :      * Infinity).  This is somewhat arbitrary; the important thing is to have
    2511             :      * a consistent sort order.
    2512             :      */
    2513     6446580 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1))
    2514             :     {
    2515        8828 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(num1))
    2516             :         {
    2517        8738 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(num2))
    2518        1136 :                 result = 0;     /* NAN = NAN */
    2519             :             else
    2520        7602 :                 result = 1;     /* NAN > non-NAN */
    2521             :         }
    2522          90 :         else if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(num1))
    2523             :         {
    2524          72 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(num2))
    2525           0 :                 result = -1;    /* PINF < NAN */
    2526          72 :             else if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(num2))
    2527           6 :                 result = 0;     /* PINF = PINF */
    2528             :             else
    2529          66 :                 result = 1;     /* PINF > anything else */
    2530             :         }
    2531             :         else                    /* num1 must be NINF */
    2532             :         {
    2533          18 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(num2))
    2534           6 :                 result = 0;     /* NINF = NINF */
    2535             :             else
    2536          12 :                 result = -1;    /* NINF < anything else */
    2537             :         }
    2538             :     }
    2539     6437752 :     else if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num2))
    2540             :     {
    2541       11244 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(num2))
    2542          12 :             result = 1;         /* normal > NINF */
    2543             :         else

    2557             : /*
    2558             :  * in_range support function for numeric.

    2561        1152 : in_range_numeric_numeric(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)

    2567        1152 :     bool        less = PG_GETARG_BOOL(4);
    2568             :     bool        result;
    2569             : 
    2570             :     /*
    2571             :      * Reject negative (including -Inf) or NaN offset.  Negative is per spec,
    2572             :      * and NaN is because appropriate semantics for that seem non-obvious.
    2573             :      */
    2574        1152 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(offset) ||
    2575        1146 :         NUMERIC_IS_NINF(offset) ||
    2576        1146 :         NUMERIC_SIGN(offset) == NUMERIC_NEG)
    2577           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    2578             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PRECEDING_OR_FOLLOWING_SIZE),
    2579             :                  errmsg("invalid preceding or following size in window function")));
    2580             : 
    2581             :     /*
    2582             :      * Deal with cases where val and/or base is NaN, following the rule that
    2583             :      * NaN sorts after non-NaN (cf cmp_numerics).  The offset cannot affect
    2584             :      * the conclusion.
    2585             :      */
    2586        1146 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(val))
    2587             :     {
    2588         186 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(base))
    2589          60 :             result = true;      /* NAN = NAN */
    2590             :         else
    2591         126 :             result = !less;     /* NAN > non-NAN */
    2592             :     }
    2593         960 :     else if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(base))
    2594             :     {
    2595         126 :         result = less;          /* non-NAN < NAN */
    2596             :     }
    2597             : 
    2598             :     /*
    2599             :      * Deal with infinite offset (necessarily +Inf, at this point).
    2600             :      */
    2601         834 :     else if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(offset))
    2602             :     {
    2603         420 :         Assert(NUMERIC_IS_PINF(offset));

    2605             :         {
    2606             :             /*
    2607             :              * base +/- offset would produce NaN, so return true for any val

    2610         174 :             result = true;
    2611             :         }
    2612         246 :         else if (sub)
    2613             :         {
    2614             :             /* base - offset must be -inf */
    2615         150 :             if (less)
    2616          54 :                 result = NUMERIC_IS_NINF(val);  /* only -inf is <= sum */
    2617             :             else
    2618          96 :                 result = true;  /* any val is >= sum */
    2619             :         }
    2620             :         else
    2621             :         {
    2622             :             /* base + offset must be +inf */
    2623          96 :             if (less)
    2624           0 :                 result = true;  /* any val is <= sum */
    2625             :             else
    2626          96 :                 result = NUMERIC_IS_PINF(val);  /* only +inf is >= sum */
    2627             :         }
    2628             :     }
    2629             : 
    2630             :     /*
    2631             :      * Deal with cases where val and/or base is infinite.  The offset, being
    2632             :      * now known finite, cannot affect the conclusion.
    2633             :      */
    2634         414 :     else if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(val))
    2635             :     {
    2636          78 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(val))
    2637             :         {
    2638          36 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(base))
    2639          24 :                 result = true;  /* PINF = PINF */
    2640             :             else
    2641          12 :                 result = !less; /* PINF > any other non-NAN */
    2642             :         }
    2643             :         else                    /* val must be NINF */

    2645          42 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(base))

    2647             :             else
    2648          12 :                 result = less;  /* NINF < anything else */

    2651         336 :     else if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(base))
    2652             :     {

    2654          12 :             result = !less;     /* normal > NINF */
    2655             :         else
    2656          12 :             result = less;      /* normal < PINF */
    2657             :     }
    2658             :     else
    2659             :     {
    2660             :         /*

    2662             :          * possible for this to overflow the numeric format, it's unlikely

    2696      592026 : hash_numeric(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)

    2703             :     int         end_offset;
    2704             :     int         i;
    2705             :     int         hash_len;
    2706             :     NumericDigit *digits;
    2707             : 
    2708             :     /* If it's NaN or infinity, don't try to hash the rest of the fields */
    2709      592026 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(key))
    2710           0 :         PG_RETURN_UINT32(0);
    2711             : 
    2712      592026 :     weight = NUMERIC_WEIGHT(key);
    2713      592026 :     start_offset = 0;
    2714      592026 :     end_offset = 0;
    2715             : 
    2716             :     /*
    2717             :      * Omit any leading or trailing zeros from the input to the hash. The
    2718             :      * numeric implementation *should* guarantee that leading and trailing
    2719             :      * zeros are suppressed, but we're paranoid. Note that we measure the
    2720             :      * starting and ending offsets in units of NumericDigits, not bytes.
    2721             :      */
    2722      592026 :     digits = NUMERIC_DIGITS(key);
    2723      592026 :     for (i = 0; i < NUMERIC_NDIGITS(key); i++)
    2724             :     {
    2725      590532 :         if (digits[i] != (NumericDigit) 0)
    2726      590532 :             break;
    2727             : 
    2728           0 :         start_offset++;
    2729             : 
    2730             :         /*
    2731             :          * The weight is effectively the # of digits before the decimal point,
    2732             :          * so decrement it for each leading zero we skip.
    2733             :          */
    2734           0 :         weight--;
    2735             :     }
    2736             : 
    2737             :     /*
    2738             :      * If there are no non-zero digits, then the value of the number is zero,
    2739             :      * regardless of any other fields.
    2740             :      */
    2741      592026 :     if (NUMERIC_NDIGITS(key) == start_offset)
    2742        1494 :         PG_RETURN_UINT32(-1);
    2743             : 
    2744      590532 :     for (i = NUMERIC_NDIGITS(key) - 1; i >= 0; i--)
    2745             :     {
    2746      590532 :         if (digits[i] != (NumericDigit) 0)
    2747      590532 :             break;
    2748             : 
    2749           0 :         end_offset++;
    2750             :     }
    2751             : 
    2752             :     /* If we get here, there should be at least one non-zero digit */
    2753      590532 :     Assert(start_offset + end_offset < NUMERIC_NDIGITS(key));
    2754             : 
    2755             :     /*
    2756             :      * Note that we don't hash on the Numeric's scale, since two numerics can
    2757             :      * compare equal but have different scales. We also don't hash on the
    2758             :      * sign, although we could: since a sign difference implies inequality,
    2759             :      * this shouldn't affect correctness.
    2760             :      */
    2761      590532 :     hash_len = NUMERIC_NDIGITS(key) - start_offset - end_offset;
    2762      590532 :     digit_hash = hash_any((unsigned char *) (NUMERIC_DIGITS(key) + start_offset),
    2763             :                           hash_len * sizeof(NumericDigit));
    2764             : 
    2765             :     /* Mix in the weight, via XOR */
    2766      590532 :     result = digit_hash ^ weight;
    2767             : 
    2768      590532 :     PG_RETURN_DATUM(result);
    2769             : }

    3068           6 :                     return make_result(&const_nan); /* 0 * Inf */

    3070          12 :                     return make_result(&const_pinf);
    3071           6 :                 case -1:
    3072           6 :                     return make_result(&const_ninf);
    3073             :             }
    3074           0 :             Assert(false);
    3075             :         }
    3076          24 :         Assert(NUMERIC_IS_NINF(num2));

    3078             :         {

    3080           6 :                 return make_result(&const_nan); /* 0 * -Inf */

    3082          12 :                 return make_result(&const_ninf);
    3083           6 :             case -1:
    3084           6 :                 return make_result(&const_pinf);

    3087             :     }
    3088             : 
    3089             :     /*
    3090             :      * Unpack the values, let mul_var() compute the result and return it.
    3091             :      * Unlike add_var() and sub_var(), mul_var() will round its result. In the
    3092             :      * case of numeric_mul(), which is invoked for the * operator on numerics,
    3093             :      * we request exact representation for the product (rscale = sum(dscale of
    3094             :      * arg1, dscale of arg2)).  If the exact result has more digits after the
    3095             :      * decimal point than can be stored in a numeric, we round it.  Rounding
    3096             :      * after computing the exact result ensures that the final result is
    3097             :      * correctly rounded (rounding in mul_var() using a truncated product
    3098             :      * would not guarantee this).
    3099             :      */

    3101      489510 :     init_var_from_num(num2, &arg2);
    3102             : 
    3103      489510 :     init_var(&result);
    3104      489510 :     mul_var(&arg1, &arg2, &result, arg1.dscale + arg2.dscale);
    3105             : 
    3106      489510 :     if (result.dscale > NUMERIC_DSCALE_MAX)
    3107           6 :         round_var(&result, NUMERIC_DSCALE_MAX);
    3108             : 
    3109      489510 :     res = make_result_opt_error(&result, have_error);
    3110             : 
    3111      489510 :     free_var(&result);
    3112             : 
    3113      489510 :     return res;
    3114             : }

    3557             : /*
    3558             :  * numeric_lcm() -
    3559             :  *
    3560             :  *  Calculate the least common multiple of two numerics
    3561             :  */
    3562             : Datum
    3563         246 : numeric_lcm(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)
    3564             : {
    3565         246 :     Numeric     num1 = PG_GETARG_NUMERIC(0);
    3566         246 :     Numeric     num2 = PG_GETARG_NUMERIC(1);
    3567             :     NumericVar  arg1;
    3568             :     NumericVar  arg2;
    3569             :     NumericVar  result;
    3570             :     Numeric     res;
    3571             : 
    3572             :     /*
    3573             :      * Handle NaN and infinities: we consider the result to be NaN in all such
    3574             :      * cases.
    3575             :      */
    3576         246 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1) || NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num2))
    3577          96 :         PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_nan));
    3578             : 
    3579             :     /*
    3580             :      * Unpack the arguments
    3581             :      */
    3582         150 :     init_var_from_num(num1, &arg1);
    3583         150 :     init_var_from_num(num2, &arg2);
    3584             : 
    3585         150 :     init_var(&result);
    3586             : 
    3587             :     /*
    3588             :      * Compute the result using lcm(x, y) = abs(x / gcd(x, y) * y), returning
    3589             :      * zero if either input is zero.
    3590             :      *
    3591             :      * Note that the division is guaranteed to be exact, returning an integer
    3592             :      * result, so the LCM is an integral multiple of both x and y.  A display
    3593             :      * scale of Min(x.dscale, y.dscale) would be sufficient to represent it,
    3594             :      * but as with other numeric functions, we choose to return a result whose
    3595             :      * display scale is no smaller than either input.
    3596             :      */
    3597         150 :     if (arg1.ndigits == 0 || arg2.ndigits == 0)
    3598          48 :         set_var_from_var(&const_zero, &result);
    3599             :     else
    3600             :     {
    3601         102 :         gcd_var(&arg1, &arg2, &result);
    3602         102 :         div_var(&arg1, &result, &result, 0, false);
    3603         102 :         mul_var(&arg2, &result, &result, arg2.dscale);
    3604         102 :         result.sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    3605             :     }
    3606             : 
    3607         150 :     result.dscale = Max(arg1.dscale, arg2.dscale);
    3608             : 
    3609         150 :     res = make_result(&result);
    3610             : 
    3611         144 :     free_var(&result);
    3612             : 
    3613         144 :     PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(res);

    3682             :     int         rscale;
    3683             : 
    3684             :     /*
    3685             :      * Handle NaN and infinities
    3686             :      */
    3687         150 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num))
    3688             :     {
    3689             :         /* error should match that in sqrt_var() */
    3690          18 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(num))
    3691           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3692             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
    3693             :                      errmsg("cannot take square root of a negative number")));
    3694             :         /* For NAN or PINF, just duplicate the input */
    3695          12 :         PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(duplicate_numeric(num));
    3696             :     }
    3697             : 
    3698             :     /*
    3699             :      * Unpack the argument and determine the result scale.  We choose a scale
    3700             :      * to give at least NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS significant digits; but in any
    3701             :      * case not less than the input's dscale.
    3702             :      */
    3703         132 :     init_var_from_num(num, &arg);
    3704             : 
    3705         132 :     init_var(&result);
    3706             : 
    3707             :     /*
    3708             :      * Assume the input was normalized, so arg.weight is accurate.  The result
    3709             :      * then has at least sweight = floor(arg.weight * DEC_DIGITS / 2 + 1)
    3710             :      * digits before the decimal point.  When DEC_DIGITS is even, we can save
    3711             :      * a few cycles, since the division is exact and there is no need to round
    3712             :      * towards negative infinity.
    3713             :      */
    3714             : #if DEC_DIGITS == ((DEC_DIGITS / 2) * 2)
    3715         132 :     sweight = arg.weight * DEC_DIGITS / 2 + 1;
    3716             : #else
    3717             :     if (arg.weight >= 0)
    3718             :         sweight = arg.weight * DEC_DIGITS / 2 + 1;
    3719             :     else
    3720             :         sweight = 1 - (1 - arg.weight * DEC_DIGITS) / 2;
    3721             : #endif
    3722             : 
    3723         132 :     rscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS - sweight;
    3724         132 :     rscale = Max(rscale, arg.dscale);
    3725         132 :     rscale = Max(rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
    3726         132 :     rscale = Min(rscale, NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE);
    3727             : 
    3728             :     /*
    3729             :      * Let sqrt_var() do the calculation and return the result.
    3730             :      */

    3929             :  * numeric_power() -

    3934        1386 : numeric_power(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)
    3935             : {
    3936        1386 :     Numeric     num1 = PG_GETARG_NUMERIC(0);

    3943             :                 sign2;
    3944             : 
    3945             :     /*
    3946             :      * Handle NaN and infinities
    3947             :      */
    3948        1386 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1) || NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num2))
    3949             :     {
    3950             :         /*
    3951             :          * We follow the POSIX spec for pow(3), which says that NaN ^ 0 = 1,
    3952             :          * and 1 ^ NaN = 1, while all other cases with NaN inputs yield NaN
    3953             :          * (with no error).
    3954             :          */
    3955         234 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(num1))
    3956             :         {
    3957          54 :             if (!NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num2))
    3958             :             {
    3959          36 :                 init_var_from_num(num2, &arg2);
    3960          36 :                 if (cmp_var(&arg2, &const_zero) == 0)
    3961          12 :                     PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_one));
    3962             :             }
    3963          42 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_nan));
    3964             :         }
    3965         180 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_NAN(num2))
    3966             :         {
    3967          42 :             if (!NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1))
    3968             :             {
    3969          36 :                 init_var_from_num(num1, &arg1);
    3970          36 :                 if (cmp_var(&arg1, &const_one) == 0)
    3971          12 :                     PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_one));
    3972             :             }
    3973          30 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_nan));
    3974             :         }
    3975             :         /* At least one input is infinite, but error rules still apply */
    3976         138 :         sign1 = numeric_sign_internal(num1);
    3977         138 :         sign2 = numeric_sign_internal(num2);
    3978         138 :         if (sign1 == 0 && sign2 < 0)
    3979           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3980             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
    3981             :                      errmsg("zero raised to a negative power is undefined")));
    3982         132 :         if (sign1 < 0 && !numeric_is_integral(num2))
    3983           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    3984             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
    3985             :                      errmsg("a negative number raised to a non-integer power yields a complex result")));
    3986             : 
    3987             :         /*
    3988             :          * POSIX gives this series of rules for pow(3) with infinite inputs:
    3989             :          *
    3990             :          * For any value of y, if x is +1, 1.0 shall be returned.
    3991             :          */
    3992         126 :         if (!NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1))
    3993             :         {
    3994          42 :             init_var_from_num(num1, &arg1);
    3995          42 :             if (cmp_var(&arg1, &const_one) == 0)
    3996           6 :                 PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_one));
    3997             :         }
    3998             : 
    3999             :         /*
    4000             :          * For any value of x, if y is [-]0, 1.0 shall be returned.
    4001             :          */
    4002         120 :         if (sign2 == 0)
    4003          12 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_one));
    4004             : 
    4005             :         /*
    4006             :          * For any odd integer value of y > 0, if x is [-]0, [-]0 shall be
    4007             :          * returned.  For y > 0 and not an odd integer, if x is [-]0, +0 shall
    4008             :          * be returned.  (Since we don't deal in minus zero, we need not
    4009             :          * distinguish these two cases.)
    4010             :          */
    4011         108 :         if (sign1 == 0 && sign2 > 0)
    4012           6 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_zero));
    4013             : 
    4014             :         /*
    4015             :          * If x is -1, and y is [-]Inf, 1.0 shall be returned.
    4016             :          *
    4017             :          * For |x| < 1, if y is -Inf, +Inf shall be returned.
    4018             :          *
    4019             :          * For |x| > 1, if y is -Inf, +0 shall be returned.
    4020             :          *
    4021             :          * For |x| < 1, if y is +Inf, +0 shall be returned.
    4022             :          *
    4023             :          * For |x| > 1, if y is +Inf, +Inf shall be returned.
    4024             :          */
    4025         102 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_INF(num2))
    4026             :         {
    4027             :             bool        abs_x_gt_one;
    4028             : 
    4029          54 :             if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(num1))
    4030          24 :                 abs_x_gt_one = true;    /* x is either Inf or -Inf */
    4031             :             else
    4032             :             {
    4033          30 :                 init_var_from_num(num1, &arg1);
    4034          30 :                 if (cmp_var(&arg1, &const_minus_one) == 0)
    4035           6 :                     PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_one));
    4036          24 :                 arg1.sign = NUMERIC_POS;    /* now arg1 = abs(x) */
    4037          24 :                 abs_x_gt_one = (cmp_var(&arg1, &const_one) > 0);
    4038             :             }
    4039          48 :             if (abs_x_gt_one == (sign2 > 0))
    4040          30 :                 PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_pinf));
    4041             :             else
    4042          18 :                 PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_zero));
    4043             :         }
    4044             : 
    4045             :         /*
    4046             :          * For y < 0, if x is +Inf, +0 shall be returned.
    4047             :          *
    4048             :          * For y > 0, if x is +Inf, +Inf shall be returned.
    4049             :          */
    4050          48 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(num1))
    4051             :         {
    4052          24 :             if (sign2 > 0)
    4053          18 :                 PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_pinf));
    4054             :             else
    4055           6 :                 PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_zero));
    4056             :         }
    4057             : 
    4058          24 :         Assert(NUMERIC_IS_NINF(num1));
    4059             : 
    4060             :         /*
    4061             :          * For y an odd integer < 0, if x is -Inf, -0 shall be returned.  For
    4062             :          * y < 0 and not an odd integer, if x is -Inf, +0 shall be returned.
    4063             :          * (Again, we need not distinguish these two cases.)
    4064             :          */
    4065          24 :         if (sign2 < 0)
    4066          12 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_zero));
    4067             : 
    4068             :         /*
    4069             :          * For y an odd integer > 0, if x is -Inf, -Inf shall be returned. For
    4070             :          * y > 0 and not an odd integer, if x is -Inf, +Inf shall be returned.
    4071             :          */
    4072          12 :         init_var_from_num(num2, &arg2);
    4073          12 :         if (arg2.ndigits > 0 && arg2.ndigits == arg2.weight + 1 &&
    4074          12 :             (arg2.digits[arg2.ndigits - 1] & 1))
    4075           6 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_ninf));
    4076             :         else
    4077           6 :             PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(make_result(&const_pinf));
    4078             :     }
    4079             : 
    4080             :     /*
    4081             :      * The SQL spec requires that we emit a particular SQLSTATE error code for
    4082             :      * certain error conditions.  Specifically, we don't return a
    4083             :      * divide-by-zero error code for 0 ^ -1.  Raising a negative number to a
    4084             :      * non-integer power must produce the same error code, but that case is
    4085             :      * handled in power_var().
    4086             :      */
    4087        1152 :     sign1 = numeric_sign_internal(num1);
    4088        1152 :     sign2 = numeric_sign_internal(num2);
    4089             : 
    4090        1152 :     if (sign1 == 0 && sign2 < 0)
    4091          12 :         ereport(ERROR,
    4092             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
    4093             :                  errmsg("zero raised to a negative power is undefined")));
    4094             : 
    4095             :     /*
    4096             :      * Initialize things
    4097             :      */
    4098        1140 :     init_var(&result);
    4099        1140 :     init_var_from_num(num1, &arg1);
    4100        1140 :     init_var_from_num(num2, &arg2);
    4101             : 
    4102             :     /*
    4103             :      * Call power_var() to compute and return the result; note it handles
    4104             :      * scale selection itself.
    4105             :      */
    4106        1140 :     power_var(&arg1, &arg2, &result);
    4107             : 
    4108        1110 :     res = make_result(&result);
    4109             : 
    4110        1110 :     free_var(&result);
    4111             : 
    4112        1110 :     PG_RETURN_NUMERIC(res);
    4113             : }
    4114             : 
    4115             : /*
    4116             :  * numeric_scale() -
    4117             :  *
    4118             :  *  Returns the scale, i.e. the count of decimal digits in the fractional part
    4119             :  */
    4120             : Datum
    4121         108 : numeric_scale(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)
    4122             : {
    4123         108 :     Numeric     num = PG_GETARG_NUMERIC(0);
    4124             :

    4131             : /*
    4132             :  * Calculate minimum scale for value.
    4133             :  */
    4134             : static int
    4135         126 : get_min_scale(NumericVar *var)
    4136             : {
    4137             :     int         min_scale;
    4138             :     int         last_digit_pos;
    4139             : 
    4140             :     /*
    4141             :      * Ordinarily, the input value will be "stripped" so that the last
    4142             :      * NumericDigit is nonzero.  But we don't want to get into an infinite
    4143             :      * loop if it isn't, so explicitly find the last nonzero digit.
    4144             :      */
    4145         126 :     last_digit_pos = var->ndigits - 1;
    4146         126 :     while (last_digit_pos >= 0 &&
    4147         102 :            var->digits[last_digit_pos] == 0)
    4148           0 :         last_digit_pos--;
    4149             : 
    4150         126 :     if (last_digit_pos >= 0)
    4151             :     {
    4152             :         /* compute min_scale assuming that last ndigit has no zeroes */
    4153         102 :         min_scale = (last_digit_pos - var->weight) * DEC_DIGITS;
    4154             : 
    4155             :         /*
    4156             :          * We could get a negative result if there are no digits after the
    4157             :          * decimal point.  In this case the min_scale must be zero.
    4158             :          */
    4159         102 :         if (min_scale > 0)
    4160             :         {
    4161             :             /*
    4162             :              * Reduce min_scale if trailing digit(s) in last NumericDigit are
    4163             :              * zero.
    4164             :              */
    4165          66 :             NumericDigit last_digit = var->digits[last_digit_pos];
    4166             : 
    4167         198 :             while (last_digit % 10 == 0)
    4168             :             {
    4169         132 :                 min_scale--;
    4170         132 :                 last_digit /= 10;
    4171             :             }
    4172             :         }
    4173             :         else
    4174          36 :             min_scale = 0;
    4175             :     }
    4176             :     else
    4177          24 :         min_scale = 0;          /* result if input is zero */
    4178             : 
    4179         126 :     return min_scale;
    4180             : }
    4181             : 
    4182             : /*
    4183             :  * Returns minimum scale required to represent supplied value without loss.
    4184             :  */

    4248             : /*
    4249             :  * Convert val1/(10**log10val2) to numeric.  This is much faster than normal
    4250             :  * numeric division.
    4251             :  */
    4252             : Numeric
    4253       29200 : int64_div_fast_to_numeric(int64 val1, int log10val2)
    4254             : {
    4255             :     Numeric     res;
    4256             :     NumericVar  result;
    4257             :     int         rscale;
    4258             :     int         w;
    4259             :     int         m;
    4260             : 
    4261       29200 :     init_var(&result);
    4262             : 
    4263             :     /* result scale */
    4264       29200 :     rscale = log10val2 < 0 ? 0 : log10val2;
    4265             : 
    4266             :     /* how much to decrease the weight by */
    4267       29200 :     w = log10val2 / DEC_DIGITS;
    4268             :     /* how much is left to divide by */
    4269       29200 :     m = log10val2 % DEC_DIGITS;
    4270       29200 :     if (m < 0)
    4271             :     {
    4272           0 :         m += DEC_DIGITS;
    4273           0 :         w--;
    4274             :     }
    4275             : 
    4276             :     /*
    4277             :      * If there is anything left to divide by (10^m with 0 < m < DEC_DIGITS),
    4278             :      * multiply the dividend by 10^(DEC_DIGITS - m), and shift the weight by
    4279             :      * one more.
    4280             :      */
    4281       29200 :     if (m > 0)
    4282             :     {
    4283             : #if DEC_DIGITS == 4
    4284             :         static const int pow10[] = {1, 10, 100, 1000};
    4285             : #elif DEC_DIGITS == 2
    4286             :         static const int pow10[] = {1, 10};
    4287             : #elif DEC_DIGITS == 1
    4288             :         static const int pow10[] = {1};
    4289             : #else
    4290             : #error unsupported NBASE
    4291             : #endif
    4292       29200 :         int64       factor = pow10[DEC_DIGITS - m];
    4293             :         int64       new_val1;
    4294             : 
    4295             :         StaticAssertDecl(lengthof(pow10) == DEC_DIGITS, "mismatch with DEC_DIGITS");
    4296             : 
    4297       29200 :         if (unlikely(pg_mul_s64_overflow(val1, factor, &new_val1)))
    4298             :         {
    4299             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
    4300             :             /* do the multiplication using 128-bit integers */
    4301             :             int128      tmp;
    4302             : 
    4303          12 :             tmp = (int128) val1 * (int128) factor;
    4304             : 
    4305          12 :             int128_to_numericvar(tmp, &result);
    4306             : #else
    4307             :             /* do the multiplication using numerics */
    4308             :             NumericVar  tmp;
    4309             : 
    4310             :             init_var(&tmp);
    4311             : 
    4312             :             int64_to_numericvar(val1, &result);
    4313             :             int64_to_numericvar(factor, &tmp);
    4314             :             mul_var(&result, &tmp, &result, 0);
    4315             : 
    4316             :             free_var(&tmp);
    4317             : #endif
    4318             :         }
    4319             :         else
    4320       29188 :             int64_to_numericvar(new_val1, &result);
    4321             : 
    4322       29200 :         w++;
    4323             :     }
    4324             :     else
    4325           0 :         int64_to_numericvar(val1, &result);
    4326             : 
    4327       29200 :     result.weight -= w;
    4328       29200 :     result.dscale = rscale;
    4329             : 
    4330       29200 :     res = make_result(&result);
    4331             : 
    4332       29200 :     free_var(&result);
    4333             :

    4702             :     NumericVar  x;
    4703             :     XLogRecPtr  result;

    4706             :     {

    4708           6 :             ereport(ERROR,
    4709             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),

    4713             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),

    4723             :                  errmsg("pg_lsn out of range")));

    4727             : 
    4728             : 
    4729             : /* ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    4730             :  *
    4731             :  * Aggregate functions
    4732             :  *
    4733             :  * The transition datatype for all these aggregates is declared as INTERNAL.
    4734             :  * Actually, it's a pointer to a NumericAggState allocated in the aggregate
    4735             :  * context.  The digit buffers for the NumericVars will be there too.
    4736             :  *
    4737             :  * On platforms which support 128-bit integers some aggregates instead use a
    4738             :  * 128-bit integer based transition datatype to speed up calculations.
    4739             :  *
    4740             :  * ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    4741             :  */
    4742             : 
    4743             : typedef struct NumericAggState
    4744             : {
    4745             :     bool        calcSumX2;      /* if true, calculate sumX2 */
    4746             :     MemoryContext agg_context;  /* context we're calculating in */
    4747             :     int64       N;              /* count of processed numbers */
    4748             :     NumericSumAccum sumX;       /* sum of processed numbers */
    4749             :     NumericSumAccum sumX2;      /* sum of squares of processed numbers */
    4750             :     int         maxScale;       /* maximum scale seen so far */
    4751             :     int64       maxScaleCount;  /* number of values seen with maximum scale */
    4752             :     /* These counts are *not* included in N!  Use NA_TOTAL_COUNT() as needed */
    4753             :     int64       NaNcount;       /* count of NaN values */
    4754             :     int64       pInfcount;      /* count of +Inf values */
    4755             :     int64       nInfcount;      /* count of -Inf values */
    4756             : } NumericAggState;
    4757             : 
    4758             : #define NA_TOTAL_COUNT(na) \
    4759             :     ((na)->N + (na)->NaNcount + (na)->pInfcount + (na)->nInfcount)
    4760             : 
    4761             : /*
    4762             :  * Prepare state data for a numeric aggregate function that needs to compute
    4763             :  * sum, count and optionally sum of squares of the input.
    4764             :  */
    4765             : static NumericAggState *
    4766      171140 : makeNumericAggState(FunctionCallInfo fcinfo, bool calcSumX2)
    4767             : {
    4768             :     NumericAggState *state;
    4769             :     MemoryContext agg_context;
    4770             :     MemoryContext old_context;
    4771             : 
    4772      171140 :     if (!AggCheckCallContext(fcinfo, &agg_context))
    4773           0 :         elog(ERROR, "aggregate function called in non-aggregate context");
    4774             : 
    4775      171140 :     old_context = MemoryContextSwitchTo(agg_context);
    4776             : 
    4777      171140 :     state = (NumericAggState *) palloc0(sizeof(NumericAggState));
    4778      171140 :     state->calcSumX2 = calcSumX2;
    4779      171140 :     state->agg_context = agg_context;
    4780             : 
    4781      171140 :     MemoryContextSwitchTo(old_context);
    4782             : 
    4783      171140 :     return state;
    4784             : }
    4785             : 
    4786             : /*
    4787             :  * Like makeNumericAggState(), but allocate the state in the current memory
    4788             :  * context.
    4789             :  */
    4790             : static NumericAggState *
    4791          84 : makeNumericAggStateCurrentContext(bool calcSumX2)
    4792             : {
    4793             :     NumericAggState *state;
    4794             : 
    4795          84 :     state = (NumericAggState *) palloc0(sizeof(NumericAggState));
    4796          84 :     state->calcSumX2 = calcSumX2;

    4800             : }
    4801             : 
    4802             : /*
    4803             :  * Accumulate a new input value for numeric aggregate functions.
    4804             :  */
    4805             : static void
    4806     2113552 : do_numeric_accum(NumericAggState *state, Numeric newval)
    4807             : {
    4808             :     NumericVar  X;
    4809             :     NumericVar  X2;
    4810             :     MemoryContext old_context;
    4811             : 
    4812             :     /* Count NaN/infinity inputs separately from all else */
    4813     2113552 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(newval))
    4814             :     {
    4815         162 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(newval))
    4816          72 :             state->pInfcount++;
    4817          90 :         else if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(newval))
    4818          36 :             state->nInfcount++;
    4819             :         else
    4820          54 :             state->NaNcount++;
    4821         162 :         return;
    4822             :     }
    4823             : 
    4824             :     /* load processed number in short-lived context */
    4825     2113390 :     init_var_from_num(newval, &X);
    4826             : 
    4827             :     /*
    4828             :      * Track the highest input dscale that we've seen, to support inverse
    4829             :      * transitions (see do_numeric_discard).
    4830             :      */
    4831     2113390 :     if (X.dscale > state->maxScale)
    4832             :     {
    4833         156 :         state->maxScale = X.dscale;
    4834         156 :         state->maxScaleCount = 1;
    4835             :     }
    4836     2113234 :     else if (X.dscale == state->maxScale)
    4837     2113198 :         state->maxScaleCount++;
    4838             : 
    4839             :     /* if we need X^2, calculate that in short-lived context */
    4840     2113390 :     if (state->calcSumX2)
    4841             :     {
    4842      240732 :         init_var(&X2);
    4843      240732 :         mul_var(&X, &X, &X2, X.dscale * 2);
    4844             :     }
    4845             : 
    4846             :     /* The rest of this needs to work in the aggregate context */
    4847     2113390 :     old_context = MemoryContextSwitchTo(state->agg_context);
    4848             : 
    4849     2113390 :     state->N++;
    4850             : 
    4851             :     /* Accumulate sums */
    4852     2113390 :     accum_sum_add(&(state->sumX), &X);
    4853             : 
    4854     2113390 :     if (state->calcSumX2)
    4855      240732 :         accum_sum_add(&(state->sumX2), &X2);
    4856             : 
    4857     2113390 :     MemoryContextSwitchTo(old_context);
    4858             : }
    4859             : 
    4860             : /*
    4861             :  * Attempt to remove an input value from the aggregated state.
    4862             :  *
    4863             :  * If the value cannot be removed then the function will return false; the
    4864             :  * possible reasons for failing are described below.
    4865             :  *
    4866             :  * If we aggregate the values 1.01 and 2 then the result will be 3.01.
    4867             :  * If we are then asked to un-aggregate the 1.01 then we must fail as we
    4868             :  * won't be able to tell what the new aggregated value's dscale should be.
    4869             :  * We don't want to return 2.00 (dscale = 2), since the sum's dscale would
    4870             :  * have been zero if we'd really aggregated only 2.
    4871             :  *
    4872             :  * Note: alternatively, we could count the number of inputs with each possible
    4873             :  * dscale (up to some sane limit).  Not yet clear if it's worth the trouble.
    4874             :  */
    4875             : static bool
    4876         342 : do_numeric_discard(NumericAggState *state, Numeric newval)
    4877             : {
    4878             :     NumericVar  X;
    4879             :     NumericVar  X2;
    4880             :     MemoryContext old_context;
    4881             : 
    4882             :     /* Count NaN/infinity inputs separately from all else */
    4883         342 :     if (NUMERIC_IS_SPECIAL(newval))
    4884             :     {
    4885           6 :         if (NUMERIC_IS_PINF(newval))
    4886           0 :             state->pInfcount--;
    4887           6 :         else if (NUMERIC_IS_NINF(newval))
    4888           0 :             state->nInfcount--;
    4889             :         else
    4890           6 :             state->NaNcount--;
    4891           6 :         return true;
    4892             :     }
    4893             : 
    4894             :     /* load processed number in short-lived context */
    4895         336 :     init_var_from_num(newval, &X);
    4896             : 
    4897             :     /*
    4898             :      * state->sumX's dscale is the maximum dscale of any of the inputs.
    4899             :      * Removing the last input with that dscale would require us to recompute
    4900             :      * the maximum dscale of the *remaining* inputs, which we cannot do unless
    4901             :      * no more non-NaN inputs remain at all.  So we report a failure instead,
    4902             :      * and force the aggregation to be redone from scratch.
    4903             :      */
    4904         336 :     if (X.dscale == state->maxScale)
    4905             :     {
    4906         336 :         if (state->maxScaleCount > 1 || state->maxScale == 0)
    4907             :         {
    4908             :             /*
    4909             :              * Some remaining inputs have same dscale, or dscale hasn't gotten
    4910             :              * above zero anyway
    4911             :              */
    4912         318 :             state->maxScaleCount--;
    4913             :         }
    4914          18 :         else if (state->N == 1)
    4915             :         {
    4916             :             /* No remaining non-NaN inputs at all, so reset maxScale */
    4917          12 :             state->maxScale = 0;
    4918          12 :             state->maxScaleCount = 0;
    4919             :         }
    4920             :         else
    4921             :         {
    4922             :             /* Correct new maxScale is uncertain, must fail */
    4923           6 :             return false;
    4924             :         }
    4925             :     }
    4926             : 
    4927             :     /* if we need X^2, calculate that in short-lived context */
    4928         330 :     if (state->calcSumX2)
    4929             :     {
    4930         288 :         init_var(&X2);
    4931         288 :         mul_var(&X, &X, &X2, X.dscale * 2);
    4932             :     }
    4933             : 
    4934             :     /* The rest of this needs to work in the aggregate context */
    4935         330 :     old_context = MemoryContextSwitchTo(state->agg_context);
    4936             : 
    4937         330 :     if (state->N-- > 1)
    4938             :     {
    4939             :         /* Negate X, to subtract it from the sum */
    4940         312 :         X.sign = (X.sign == NUMERIC_POS ? NUMERIC_NEG : NUMERIC_POS);
    4941         312 :         accum_sum_add(&(state->sumX), &X);
    4942             : 
    4943         312 :         if (state->calcSumX2)
    4944             :         {
    4945             :             /* Negate X^2. X^2 is always positive */
    4946         288 :             X2.sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
    4947         288 :             accum_sum_add(&(state->sumX2), &X2);
    4948             :         }
    4949             :     }
    4950             :     else
    4951             :     {
    4952             :         /* Zero the sums */
    4953          18 :         Assert(state->N == 0);
    4954             : 
    4955          18 :         accum_sum_reset(&state->sumX);
    4956          18 :         if (state->calcSumX2)
    4957           0 :             accum_sum_reset(&state->sumX2);
    4958             :     }
    4959             : 
    4960         330 :     MemoryContextSwitchTo(old_context);
    4961             : 
    4962         330 :     return true;
    4963             : }
    4964             : 
    4965             : /*
    4966             :  * Generic transition function for numeric aggregates that require sumX2.

    5398             : }
    5399             : 
    5400             : 
    5401             : /*
    5402             :  * Integer data types in general use Numeric accumulators to share code
    5403             :  * and avoid risk of overflow.
    5404             :  *
    5405             :  * However for performance reasons optimized special-purpose accumulator
    5406             :  * routines are used when possible.
    5407             :  *
    5408             :  * On platforms with 128-bit integer support, the 128-bit routines will be
    5409             :  * used when sum(X) or sum(X*X) fit into 128-bit.
    5410             :  *
    5411             :  * For 16 and 32 bit inputs, the N and sum(X) fit into 64-bit so the 64-bit
    5412             :  * accumulators will be used for SUM and AVG of these data types.
    5413             :  */
    5414             : 
    5415             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
    5416             : typedef struct Int128AggState
    5417             : {
    5418             :     bool        calcSumX2;      /* if true, calculate sumX2 */
    5419             :     int64       N;              /* count of processed numbers */
    5420             :     int128      sumX;           /* sum of processed numbers */
    5421             :     int128      sumX2;          /* sum of squares of processed numbers */
    5422             : } Int128AggState;
    5423             : 
    5424             : /*
    5425             :  * Prepare state data for a 128-bit aggregate function that needs to compute
    5426             :  * sum, count and optionally sum of squares of the input.
    5427             :  */
    5428             : static Int128AggState *
    5429         688 : makeInt128AggState(FunctionCallInfo fcinfo, bool calcSumX2)
    5430             : {
    5431             :     Int128AggState *state;
    5432             :     MemoryContext agg_context;
    5433             :     MemoryContext old_context;
    5434             : 
    5435         688 :     if (!AggCheckCallContext(fcinfo, &agg_context))
    5436           0 :         elog(ERROR, "aggregate function called in non-aggregate context");
    5437             : 
    5438         688 :     old_context = MemoryContextSwitchTo(agg_context);
    5439             : 
    5440         688 :     state = (Int128AggState *) palloc0(sizeof(Int128AggState));
    5441         688 :     state->calcSumX2 = calcSumX2;
    5442             : 
    5443         688 :     MemoryContextSwitchTo(old_context);
    5444             : 
    5445         688 :     return state;
    5446             : }
    5447             : 
    5448             : /*
    5449             :  * Like makeInt128AggState(), but allocate the state in the current memory
    5450             :  * context.
    5451             :  */
    5452             : static Int128AggState *
    5453          42 : makeInt128AggStateCurrentContext(bool calcSumX2)
    5454             : {

    5465             :  */

    5640             : 
    5641          18 :     state = (PolyNumAggState *) PG_GETARG_POINTER(0);
    5642             : 
    5643             :     /*
    5644             :      * If the platform supports int128 then sumX and sumX2 will be a 128 bit
    5645             :      * integer type. Here we'll convert that into a numeric type so that the
    5646             :      * combine state is in the same format for both int128 enabled machines
    5647             :      * and machines which don't support that type. The logic here is that one
    5648             :      * day we might like to send these over to another server for further
    5649             :      * processing and we want a standard format to work with.
    5650             :      */
    5651             : 
    5652          18 :     init_var(&tmp_var);
    5653             : 
    5654          18 :     pq_begintypsend(&buf);

    5659             :     /* sumX */
    5660             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
    5661          18 :     int128_to_numericvar(state->sumX, &tmp_var);
    5662             : #else
    5663             :     accum_sum_final(&state->sumX, &tmp_var);
    5664             : #endif
    5665          18 :     numericvar_serialize(&buf, &tmp_var);
    5666             : 
    5667             :     /* sumX2 */

    5669          18 :     int128_to_numericvar(state->sumX2, &tmp_var);
    5670             : #else

    5672             : #endif

    5675          18 :     result = pq_endtypsend(&buf);
    5676             :

    5678             : 
    5679          18 :     PG_RETURN_BYTEA_P(result);

    5838             : 
    5839          24 :     state = (PolyNumAggState *) PG_GETARG_POINTER(0);
    5840             : 
    5841             :     /*
    5842             :      * If the platform supports int128 then sumX will be a 128 integer type.
    5843             :      * Here we'll convert that into a numeric type so that the combine state
    5844             :      * is in the same format for both int128 enabled machines and machines
    5845             :      * which don't support that type. The logic here is that one day we might
    5846             :      * like to send these over to another server for further processing and we
    5847             :      * want a standard format to work with.
    5848             :      */
    5849             : 
    5850          24 :     init_var(&tmp_var);
    5851             : 
    5852          24 :     pq_begintypsend(&buf);
    5853             : 
    5854             :     /* N */
    5855          24 :     pq_sendint64(&buf, state->N);
    5856             : 
    5857             :     /* sumX */
    5858             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
    5859          24 :     int128_to_numericvar(state->sumX, &tmp_var);
    5860             : #else
    5861             :     accum_sum_final(&state->sumX, &tmp_var);
    5862             : #endif
    5863          24 :     numericvar_serialize(&buf, &tmp_var);
    5864             : 
    5865          24 :     result = pq_endtypsend(&buf);
    5866             : 
    5867          24 :     free_var(&tmp_var);
    5868             :

    6142             : 
    6143             : /*
    6144             :  * Workhorse routine for the standard deviance and variance
    6145             :  * aggregates. 'state' is aggregate's transition state.
    6146             :  * 'variance' specifies whether we should calculate the
    6147             :  * variance or the standard deviation. 'sample' indicates whether the
    6148             :  * caller is interested in the sample or the population
    6149             :  * variance/stddev.
    6150             :  *
    6151             :  * If appropriate variance statistic is undefined for the input,
    6152             :  * *is_null is set to true and NULL is returned.
    6153             :  */
    6154             : static Numeric
    6155         986 : numeric_stddev_internal(NumericAggState *state,
    6156             :                         bool variance, bool sample,
    6157             :                         bool *is_null)
    6158             : {
    6159             :     Numeric     res;
    6160             :     NumericVar  vN,
    6161             :                 vsumX,
    6162             :                 vsumX2,
    6163             :                 vNminus1;
    6164             :     int64       totCount;
    6165             :     int         rscale;
    6166             : 
    6167             :     /*
    6168             :      * Sample stddev and variance are undefined when N <= 1; population stddev
    6169             :      * is undefined when N == 0.  Return NULL in either case (note that NaNs
    6170             :      * and infinities count as normal inputs for this purpose).
    6171             :      */
    6172         986 :     if (state == NULL || (totCount = NA_TOTAL_COUNT(state)) == 0)
    6173             :     {
    6174           0 :         *is_null = true;
    6175           0 :         return NULL;
    6176             :     }
    6177             : 
    6178         986 :     if (sample && totCount <= 1)
    6179             :     {
    6180         132 :         *is_null = true;
    6181         132 :         return NULL;
    6182             :     }
    6183             : 
    6184         854 :     *is_null = false;
    6185             : 
    6186             :     /*
    6187             :      * Deal with NaN and infinity cases.  By analogy to the behavior of the
    6188             :      * float8 functions, any infinity input produces NaN output.
    6189             :      */
    6190         854 :     if (state->NaNcount > 0 || state->pInfcount > 0 || state->nInfcount > 0)
    6191          54 :         return make_result(&const_nan);
    6192             : 
    6193             :     /* OK, normal calculation applies */
    6194         800 :     init_var(&vN);
    6195         800 :     init_var(&vsumX);
    6196         800 :     init_var(&vsumX2);
    6197             : 
    6198         800 :     int64_to_numericvar(state->N, &vN);
    6199         800 :     accum_sum_final(&(state->sumX), &vsumX);
    6200         800 :     accum_sum_final(&(state->sumX2), &vsumX2);
    6201             : 
    6202         800 :     init_var(&vNminus1);
    6203         800 :     sub_var(&vN, &const_one, &vNminus1);
    6204             : 
    6205             :     /* compute rscale for mul_var calls */
    6206         800 :     rscale = vsumX.dscale * 2;
    6207             : 
    6208         800 :     mul_var(&vsumX, &vsumX, &vsumX, rscale);    /* vsumX = sumX * sumX */
    6209         800 :     mul_var(&vN, &vsumX2, &vsumX2, rscale); /* vsumX2 = N * sumX2 */
    6210         800 :     sub_var(&vsumX2, &vsumX, &vsumX2);  /* N * sumX2 - sumX * sumX */
    6211             : 
    6212         800 :     if (cmp_var(&vsumX2, &const_zero) <= 0)
    6213             :     {
    6214             :         /* Watch out for roundoff error producing a negative numerator */
    6215          80 :         res = make_result(&const_zero);
    6216             :     }
    6217             :     else
    6218             :     {
    6219         720 :         if (sample)
    6220         492 :             mul_var(&vN, &vNminus1, &vNminus1, 0);  /* N * (N - 1) */
    6221             :         else
    6222         228 :             mul_var(&vN, &vN, &vNminus1, 0);    /* N * N */
    6223         720 :         rscale = select_div_scale(&vsumX2, &vNminus1);
    6224         720 :         div_var(&vsumX2, &vNminus1, &vsumX, rscale, true);  /* variance */
    6225         720 :         if (!variance)
    6226         378 :             sqrt_var(&vsumX, &vsumX, rscale);   /* stddev */
    6227             : 
    6228         720 :         res = make_result(&vsumX);
    6229             :     }
    6230             : 
    6231         800 :     free_var(&vNminus1);
    6232         800 :     free_var(&vsumX);
    6233         800 :     free_var(&vsumX2);
    6234             : 
    6235         800 :     return res;
    6236             : }

    6306             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128

    6434             : }
    6435             : 
    6436             : /*
    6437             :  * SUM transition functions for integer datatypes.
    6438             :  *
    6439             :  * To avoid overflow, we use accumulators wider than the input datatype.
    6440             :  * A Numeric accumulator is needed for int8 input; for int4 and int2
    6441             :  * inputs, we use int8 accumulators which should be sufficient for practical
    6442             :  * purposes.  (The latter two therefore don't really belong in this file,
    6443             :  * but we keep them here anyway.)
    6444             :  *
    6445             :  * Because SQL defines the SUM() of no values to be NULL, not zero,
    6446             :  * the initial condition of the transition data value needs to be NULL. This
    6447             :  * means we can't rely on ExecAgg to automatically insert the first non-null
    6448             :  * data value into the transition data: it doesn't know how to do the type
    6449             :  * conversion.  The upshot is that these routines have to be marked non-strict
    6450             :  * and handle substitution of the first non-null input themselves.
    6451             :  *
    6452             :  * Note: these functions are used only in plain aggregation mode.
    6453             :  * In moving-aggregate mode, we use intX_avg_accum and intX_avg_accum_inv.
    6454             :  */
    6455             : 
    6456             : Datum
    6457          24 : int2_sum(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)
    6458             : {
    6459             :     int64       newval;
    6460             : 
    6461          24 :     if (PG_ARGISNULL(0))
    6462             :     {
    6463             :         /* No non-null input seen so far... */
    6464           6 :         if (PG_ARGISNULL(1))
    6465           0 :             PG_RETURN_NULL();   /* still no non-null */
    6466             :         /* This is the first non-null input. */
    6467           6 :         newval = (int64) PG_GETARG_INT16(1);
    6468           6 :         PG_RETURN_INT64(newval);
    6469             :     }
    6470             : 
    6471             :     /*
    6472             :      * If we're invoked as an aggregate, we can cheat and modify our first
    6473             :      * parameter in-place to avoid palloc overhead. If not, we need to return
    6474             :      * the new value of the transition variable. (If int8 is pass-by-value,
    6475             :      * then of course this is useless as well as incorrect, so just ifdef it
    6476             :      * out.)
    6477             :      */
    6478             : #ifndef USE_FLOAT8_BYVAL        /* controls int8 too */
    6479             :     if (AggCheckCallContext(fcinfo, NULL))
    6480             :     {
    6481             :         int64      *oldsum = (int64 *) PG_GETARG_POINTER(0);
    6482             : 
    6483             :         /* Leave the running sum unchanged in the new input is null */
    6484             :         if (!PG_ARGISNULL(1))
    6485             :             *oldsum = *oldsum + (int64) PG_GETARG_INT16(1);
    6486             : 
    6487             :         PG_RETURN_POINTER(oldsum);
    6488             :     }
    6489             :     else
    6490             : #endif
    6491             :     {
    6492          18 :         int64       oldsum = PG_GETARG_INT64(0);
    6493             : 
    6494             :         /* Leave sum unchanged if new input is null. */
    6495          18 :         if (PG_ARGISNULL(1))
    6496           0 :             PG_RETURN_INT64(oldsum);
    6497             : 
    6498             :         /* OK to do the addition. */
    6499          18 :         newval = oldsum + (int64) PG_GETARG_INT16(1);
    6500             : 
    6501          18 :         PG_RETURN_INT64(newval);
    6502             :     }
    6503             : }
    6504             :

    6589             : 
    6590             : /*
    6591             :  * Routines for avg(int2) and avg(int4).  The transition datatype
    6592             :  * is a two-element int8 array, holding count and sum.
    6593             :  *
    6594             :  * These functions are also used for sum(int2) and sum(int4) when
    6595             :  * operating in moving-aggregate mode, since for correct inverse transitions
    6596             :  * we need to count the inputs.
    6597             :  */
    6598             :

    6601             :     int64       count;

    6794             : /* ----------------------------------------------------------------------

    6800             : 
    6801             : #ifdef NUMERIC_DEBUG
    6802             : 
    6803             : /*
    6804             :  * dump_numeric() - Dump a value in the db storage format for debugging
    6805             :  */
    6806             : static void
    6807             : dump_numeric(const char *str, Numeric num)
    6808             : {
    6809             :     NumericDigit *digits = NUMERIC_DIGITS(num);
    6810             :     int         ndigits;
    6811             :     int         i;
    6812             : 
    6813             :     ndigits = NUMERIC_NDIGITS(num);
    6814             : 
    6815             :     printf("%s: NUMERIC w=%d d=%d ", str,
    6816             :            NUMERIC_WEIGHT(num), NUMERIC_DSCALE(num));
    6817             :     switch (NUMERIC_SIGN(num))
    6818             :     {
    6819             :         case NUMERIC_POS:
    6820             :             printf("POS");
    6821             :             break;
    6822             :         case NUMERIC_NEG:
    6823             :             printf("NEG");
    6824             :             break;
    6825             :         case NUMERIC_NAN:
    6826             :             printf("NaN");
    6827             :             break;
    6828             :         case NUMERIC_PINF:
    6829             :             printf("Infinity");
    6830             :             break;
    6831             :         case NUMERIC_NINF:
    6832             :             printf("-Infinity");
    6833             :             break;
    6834             :         default:
    6835             :             printf("SIGN=0x%x", NUMERIC_SIGN(num));
    6836             :             break;
    6837             :     }
    6838             : 
    6839             :     for (i = 0; i < ndigits; i++)
    6840             :         printf(" %0*d", DEC_DIGITS, digits[i]);
    6841             :     printf("\n");
    6842             : }
    6843             : 
    6844             : 
    6845             : /*
    6846             :  * dump_var() - Dump a value in the variable format for debugging
    6847             :  */
    6848             : static void
    6849             : dump_var(const char *str, NumericVar *var)
    6850             : {
    6851             :     int         i;
    6852             : 
    6853             :     printf("%s: VAR w=%d d=%d ", str, var->weight, var->dscale);
    6854             :     switch (var->sign)
    6855             :     {
    6856             :         case NUMERIC_POS:
    6857             :             printf("POS");
    6858             :             break;
    6859             :         case NUMERIC_NEG:
    6860             :             printf("NEG");
    6861             :             break;
    6862             :         case NUMERIC_NAN:
    6863             :             printf("NaN");
    6864             :             break;
    6865             :         case NUMERIC_PINF:
    6866             :             printf("Infinity");
    6867             :             break;
    6868             :         case NUMERIC_NINF:
    6869             :             printf("-Infinity");
    6870             :             break;
    6871             :         default:
    6872             :             printf("SIGN=0x%x", var->sign);
    6873             :             break;
    6874             :     }
    6875             : 
    6876             :     for (i = 0; i < var->ndigits; i++)
    6877             :         printf(" %0*d", DEC_DIGITS, var->digits[i]);
    6878             : 
    6879             :     printf("\n");
    6880             : }
    6881             : #endif                          /* NUMERIC_DEBUG */
    6882             : 
    6883             : 
    6884             : /* ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    6885             :  *
    6886             :  * Local functions follow
    6887             :  *
    6888             :  * In general, these do not support "special" (NaN or infinity) inputs;
    6889             :  * callers should handle those possibilities first.
    6890             :  * (There are one or two exceptions, noted in their header comments.)
    6891             :  *
    6892             :  * ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    6893             :  */
    6894             : 
    6895             : 
    6896             : /*
    6897             :  * alloc_var() -
    6898             :  *
    6899             :  *  Allocate a digit buffer of ndigits digits (plus a spare digit for rounding)
    6900             :  */
    6901             : static void
    6902     2833352 : alloc_var(NumericVar *var, int ndigits)
    6903             : {
    6904     2833352 :     digitbuf_free(var->buf);
    6905     2833352 :     var->buf = digitbuf_alloc(ndigits + 1);
    6906     2833352 :     var->buf[0] = 0;         /* spare digit for rounding */
    6907     2833352 :     var->digits = var->buf + 1;
    6908     2833352 :     var->ndigits = ndigits;
    6909     2833352 : }
    6910             : 
    6911             : 
    6912             : /*
    6913             :  * free_var() -
    6914             :  *
    6915             :  *  Return the digit buffer of a variable to the free pool
    6916             :  */
    6917             : static void
    6918     3243666 : free_var(NumericVar *var)
    6919             : {
    6920     3243666 :     digitbuf_free(var->buf);
    6921     3243666 :     var->buf = NULL;
    6922     3243666 :     var->digits = NULL;
    6923     3243666 :     var->sign = NUMERIC_NAN;
    6924     3243666 : }
    6925             : 
    6926             : 
    6927             : /*
    6928             :  * zero_var() -
    6929             :  *
    6930             :  *  Set a variable to ZERO.
    6931             :  *  Note: its dscale is not touched.
    6932             :  */
    6933             : static void
    6934       39734 : zero_var(NumericVar *var)
    6935             : {
    6936       39734 :     digitbuf_free(var->buf);
    6937       39734 :     var->buf = NULL;
    6938       39734 :     var->digits = NULL;
    6939       39734 :     var->ndigits = 0;
    6940       39734 :     var->weight = 0;         /* by convention; doesn't really matter */
    6941       39734 :     var->sign = NUMERIC_POS; /* anything but NAN... */
    6942       39734 : }
    6943             : 
    6944             : 
    6945             : /*
    6946             :  * set_var_from_str()
    6947             :  *
    6948             :  *  Parse a string and put the number into a variable
    6949             :  *
    6950             :  * This function does not handle leading or trailing spaces.  It returns
    6951             :  * the end+1 position parsed into *endptr, so that caller can check for
    6952             :  * trailing spaces/garbage if deemed necessary.
    6953             :  *
    6954             :  * cp is the place to actually start parsing; str is what to use in error
    6955             :  * reports.  (Typically cp would be the same except advanced over spaces.)
    6956             :  *
    6957             :  * Returns true on success, false on failure (if escontext points to an
    6958             :  * ErrorSaveContext; otherwise errors are thrown).
    6959             :  */
    6960             : static bool
    6961      122832 : set_var_from_str(const char *str, const char *cp,
    6962             :                  NumericVar *dest, const char **endptr,
    6963             :                  Node *escontext)
    6964             : {
    6965      122832 :     bool        have_dp = false;
    6966             :     int         i;
    6967             :     unsigned char *decdigits;
    6968      122832 :     int         sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    6969      122832 :     int         dweight = -1;
    6970             :     int         ddigits;
    6971      122832 :     int         dscale = 0;
    6972             :     int         weight;
    6973             :     int         ndigits;
    6974             :     int         offset;
    6975             :     NumericDigit *digits;
    6976             : 
    6977             :     /*
    6978             :      * We first parse the string to extract decimal digits and determine the
    6979             :      * correct decimal weight.  Then convert to NBASE representation.
    6980             :      */
    6981      122832 :     switch (*cp)
    6982             :     {
    6983           0 :         case '+':
    6984           0 :             sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    6985           0 :             cp++;
    6986           0 :             break;
    6987             : 
    6988         300 :         case '-':
    6989         300 :             sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
    6990         300 :             cp++;
    6991         300 :             break;
    6992             :     }
    6993             : 
    6994      122832 :     if (*cp == '.')
    6995             :     {
    6996         382 :         have_dp = true;
    6997         382 :         cp++;
    6998             :     }
    6999             : 
    7000      122832 :     if (!isdigit((unsigned char) *cp))
    7001           0 :         goto invalid_syntax;
    7002             : 
    7003      122832 :     decdigits = (unsigned char *) palloc(strlen(cp) + DEC_DIGITS * 2);
    7004             : 
    7005             :     /* leading padding for digit alignment later */
    7006      122832 :     memset(decdigits, 0, DEC_DIGITS);
    7007      122832 :     i = DEC_DIGITS;
    7008             : 
    7009      500914 :     while (*cp)
    7010             :     {
    7011      379204 :         if (isdigit((unsigned char) *cp))

    7013      362894 :             decdigits[i++] = *cp++ - '0';

    7015      299662 :                 dweight++;
    7016             :             else
    7017       63232 :                 dscale++;
    7018             :         }
    7019       16310 :         else if (*cp == '.')
    7020             :         {
    7021       15026 :             if (have_dp)
    7022           0 :                 goto invalid_syntax;
    7023       15026 :             have_dp = true;
    7024       15026 :             cp++;
    7025             :             /* decimal point must not be followed by underscore */
    7026       15026 :             if (*cp == '_')
    7027           6 :                 goto invalid_syntax;
    7028             :         }
    7029        1284 :         else if (*cp == '_')
    7030             :         {
    7031             :             /* underscore must be followed by more digits */

    7034          18 :                 goto invalid_syntax;
    7035             :         }

    7037        1098 :             break;

    7039             : 
    7040      122808 :     ddigits = i - DEC_DIGITS;
