    8898         480 :         return;
    8899             :     }
    8900             : #endif
    8901             : 
    8902             :     /*
    8903             :      * Otherwise, perform full long division.
    8904             :      */
    8905             : 
    8906             :     /* Result zero check */
    8907        4278 :     if (var1ndigits == 0)
    8908             :     {
    8909          24 :         zero_var(result);
    8910          24 :         result->dscale = rscale;
    8911          24 :         return;
    8912             :     }
    8913             : 
    8914             :     /*
    8915             :      * Determine the result sign, weight and number of digits to calculate.
    8916             :      * The weight figured here is correct if the emitted quotient has no
    8917             :      * leading zero digits; otherwise strip_var() will fix things up.
    8918             :      */
    8919        4254 :     if (var1->sign == var2->sign)
    8920        4194 :         res_sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    8921             :     else
    8922          60 :         res_sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
    8923        4254 :     res_weight = var1->weight - var2->weight;
    8924             :     /* The number of accurate result digits we need to produce: */
    8925        4254 :     res_ndigits = res_weight + 1 + (rscale + DEC_DIGITS - 1) / DEC_DIGITS;
    8926             :     /* ... but always at least 1 */
    8927        4254 :     res_ndigits = Max(res_ndigits, 1);
    8928             :     /* If rounding needed, figure one more digit to ensure correct result */
    8929        4254 :     if (round)
    8930        4254 :         res_ndigits++;
    8931             : 
    8932             :     /*
    8933             :      * The working dividend normally requires res_ndigits + var2ndigits
    8934             :      * digits, but make it at least var1ndigits so we can load all of var1
    8935             :      * into it.  (There will be an additional digit dividend[0] in the
    8936             :      * dividend space, but for consistency with Knuth's notation we don't
    8937             :      * count that in div_ndigits.)
    8938             :      */
    8939        4254 :     div_ndigits = res_ndigits + var2ndigits;
    8940        4254 :     div_ndigits = Max(div_ndigits, var1ndigits);
    8941             : 
    8942             :     /*
    8943             :      * We need a workspace with room for the working dividend (div_ndigits+1
    8944             :      * digits) plus room for the possibly-normalized divisor (var2ndigits
    8945             :      * digits).  It is convenient also to have a zero at divisor[0] with the
    8946             :      * actual divisor data in divisor[1 .. var2ndigits].  Transferring the
    8947             :      * digits into the workspace also allows us to realloc the result (which
    8948             :      * might be the same as either input var) before we begin the main loop.
    8949             :      * Note that we use palloc0 to ensure that divisor[0], dividend[0], and
    8950             :      * any additional dividend positions beyond var1ndigits, start out 0.
    8951             :      */
    8952             :     dividend = (NumericDigit *)
    8953        4254 :         palloc0((div_ndigits + var2ndigits + 2) * sizeof(NumericDigit));
    8954        4254 :     divisor = dividend + (div_ndigits + 1);
    8955        4254 :     memcpy(dividend + 1, var1->digits, var1ndigits * sizeof(NumericDigit));
    8956        4254 :     memcpy(divisor + 1, var2->digits, var2ndigits * sizeof(NumericDigit));
    8957             : 
    8958             :     /*
    8959             :      * Now we can realloc the result to hold the generated quotient digits.
    8960             :      */
    8961        4254 :     alloc_var(result, res_ndigits);
    8962        4254 :     res_digits = result->digits;
    8963             : 
    8964             :     /*
    8965             :      * The full multiple-place algorithm is taken from Knuth volume 2,
    8966             :      * Algorithm 4.3.1D.
    8967             :      *
    8968             :      * We need the first divisor digit to be >= NBASE/2.  If it isn't, make it
    8969             :      * so by scaling up both the divisor and dividend by the factor "d".  (The
    8970             :      * reason for allocating dividend[0] above is to leave room for possible
    8971             :      * carry here.)
    8972             :      */
    8973        4254 :     if (divisor[1] < HALF_NBASE)
    8974             :     {
    8975        4254 :         int         d = NBASE / (divisor[1] + 1);
    8976             : 
    8977        4254 :         carry = 0;
    8978      144500 :         for (i = var2ndigits; i > 0; i--)
    8979             :         {
    8980      140246 :             carry += divisor[i] * d;
    8981      140246 :             divisor[i] = carry % NBASE;
    8982      140246 :             carry = carry / NBASE;
    8983             :         }
    8984        4254 :         Assert(carry == 0);
    8985        4254 :         carry = 0;
    8986             :         /* at this point only var1ndigits of dividend can be nonzero */
    8987       36422 :         for (i = var1ndigits; i >= 0; i--)
    8988             :         {
    8989       32168 :             carry += dividend[i] * d;
    8990       32168 :             dividend[i] = carry % NBASE;
    8991       32168 :             carry = carry / NBASE;
    8992             :         }
    8993        4254 :         Assert(carry == 0);
    8994        4254 :         Assert(divisor[1] >= HALF_NBASE);
    8995             :     }
    8996             :     /* First 2 divisor digits are used repeatedly in main loop */
    8997        4254 :     divisor1 = divisor[1];
    8998        4254 :     divisor2 = divisor[2];
    8999             : 
    9000             :     /*
    9001             :      * Begin the main loop.  Each iteration of this loop produces the j'th
    9002             :      * quotient digit by dividing dividend[j .. j + var2ndigits] by the
    9003             :      * divisor; this is essentially the same as the common manual procedure
    9004             :      * for long division.
    9005             :      */
    9006       33516 :     for (j = 0; j < res_ndigits; j++)
    9007             :     {
    9008             :         /* Estimate quotient digit from the first two dividend digits */
    9009       29262 :         int         next2digits = dividend[j] * NBASE + dividend[j + 1];
    9010             :         int         qhat;
    9011             : 
    9012             :         /*
    9013             :          * If next2digits are 0, then quotient digit must be 0 and there's no
    9014             :          * need to adjust the working dividend.  It's worth testing here to
    9015             :          * fall out ASAP when processing trailing zeroes in a dividend.
    9016             :          */
    9017       29262 :         if (next2digits == 0)
    9018             :         {
    9019          72 :             res_digits[j] = 0;
    9020          72 :             continue;
    9021             :         }
    9022             : 
    9023       29190 :         if (dividend[j] == divisor1)
    9024         120 :             qhat = NBASE - 1;
    9025             :         else
    9026       29070 :             qhat = next2digits / divisor1;
    9027             : 
    9028             :         /*
    9029             :          * Adjust quotient digit if it's too large.  Knuth proves that after
    9030             :          * this step, the quotient digit will be either correct or just one
    9031             :          * too large.  (Note: it's OK to use dividend[j+2] here because we
    9032             :          * know the divisor length is at least 2.)
    9033             :          */
    9034       29190 :         while (divisor2 * qhat >
    9035       32150 :                (next2digits - qhat * divisor1) * NBASE + dividend[j + 2])
    9036        2960 :             qhat--;
    9037             : 
    9038             :         /* As above, need do nothing more when quotient digit is 0 */
    9039       29190 :         if (qhat > 0)
    9040             :         {
    9041       25660 :             NumericDigit *dividend_j = &dividend[j];
    9042             : 
    9043             :             /*
    9044             :              * Multiply the divisor by qhat, and subtract that from the
    9045             :              * working dividend.  The multiplication and subtraction are
    9046             :              * folded together here, noting that qhat <= NBASE (since it might
    9047             :              * be one too large), and so the intermediate result "tmp_result"
    9048             :              * is in the range [-NBASE^2, NBASE - 1], and "borrow" is in the
    9049             :              * range [0, NBASE].
    9050             :              */
    9051       25660 :             borrow = 0;
    9052      898684 :             for (i = var2ndigits; i >= 0; i--)
    9053             :             {
    9054             :                 int         tmp_result;
    9055             : 
    9056      873024 :                 tmp_result = dividend_j[i] - borrow - divisor[i] * qhat;
    9057      873024 :                 borrow = (NBASE - 1 - tmp_result) / NBASE;
    9058      873024 :                 dividend_j[i] = tmp_result + borrow * NBASE;
    9059             :             }
    9060             : 
    9061             :             /*
    9062             :              * If we got a borrow out of the top dividend digit, then indeed
    9063             :              * qhat was one too large.  Fix it, and add back the divisor to
    9064             :              * correct the working dividend.  (Knuth proves that this will
    9065             :              * occur only about 3/NBASE of the time; hence, it's a good idea
    9066             :              * to test this code with small NBASE to be sure this section gets
    9067             :              * exercised.)
    9068             :              */
    9069       25660 :             if (borrow)
    9070             :             {
    9071          26 :                 qhat--;
    9072          26 :                 carry = 0;
    9073        2308 :                 for (i = var2ndigits; i >= 0; i--)
    9074             :                 {
    9075        2282 :                     carry += dividend_j[i] + divisor[i];
    9076        2282 :                     if (carry >= NBASE)
    9077             :                     {
    9078        2094 :                         dividend_j[i] = carry - NBASE;
    9079        2094 :                         carry = 1;
    9080             :                     }
    9081             :                     else
    9082             :                     {
    9083         188 :                         dividend_j[i] = carry;
    9084         188 :                         carry = 0;
    9085             :                     }
    9086             :                 }
    9087             :                 /* A carry should occur here to cancel the borrow above */
    9088          26 :                 Assert(carry == 1);
    9089             :             }
    9090             :         }
    9091             : 
    9092             :         /* And we're done with this quotient digit */
    9093       29190 :         res_digits[j] = qhat;
    9094             :     }
    9095             : 
    9096        4254 :     pfree(dividend);
    9097             : 
    9098             :     /*
    9099             :      * Finally, round or truncate the result to the requested precision.
    9100             :      */
    9101        4254 :     result->weight = res_weight;
    9102        4254 :     result->sign = res_sign;
    9103             : 
    9104             :     /* Round or truncate to target rscale (and set result->dscale) */
    9105        4254 :     if (round)
    9106        4254 :         round_var(result, rscale);
    9107             :     else
    9108           0 :         trunc_var(result, rscale);
    9109             : 
    9110             :     /* Strip leading and trailing zeroes */
    9111        4254 :     strip_var(result);
    9112             : }
    9113             : 
    9114             : 
    9115             : /*
    9116             :  * div_var_fast() -
    9117             :  *
    9118             :  *  This has the same API as div_var, but is implemented using the division
    9119             :  *  algorithm from the "FM" library, rather than Knuth's schoolbook-division
    9120             :  *  approach.  This is significantly faster but can produce inaccurate
    9121             :  *  results, because it sometimes has to propagate rounding to the left,
    9122             :  *  and so we can never be entirely sure that we know the requested digits
    9123             :  *  exactly.  We compute DIV_GUARD_DIGITS extra digits, but there is
    9124             :  *  no certainty that that's enough.  We use this only in the transcendental
    9125             :  *  function calculation routines, where everything is approximate anyway.
    9126             :  *
    9127             :  *  Although we provide a "round" argument for consistency with div_var,
    9128             :  *  it is unwise to use this function with round=false.  In truncation mode
    9129             :  *  it is possible to get a result with no significant digits, for example
    9130             :  *  with rscale=0 we might compute 0.99999... and truncate that to 0 when
    9131             :  *  the correct answer is 1.
    9132             :  */
    9133             : static void
    9134        5802 : div_var_fast(const NumericVar *var1, const NumericVar *var2,
    9135             :              NumericVar *result, int rscale, bool round)
    9136             : {
    9137             :     int         div_ndigits;
    9138             :     int         load_ndigits;
    9139             :     int         res_sign;
    9140             :     int         res_weight;
    9141             :     int        *div;
    9142             :     int         qdigit;
    9143             :     int         carry;
    9144             :     int         maxdiv;
    9145             :     int         newdig;
    9146             :     NumericDigit *res_digits;
    9147             :     double      fdividend,
    9148             :                 fdivisor,
    9149             :                 fdivisorinverse,
    9150             :                 fquotient;
    9151             :     int         qi;
    9152             :     int         i;
    9153             : 
    9154             :     /* copy these values into local vars for speed in inner loop */
    9155        5802 :     int         var1ndigits = var1->ndigits;
    9156        5802 :     int         var2ndigits = var2->ndigits;
    9157        5802 :     NumericDigit *var1digits = var1->digits;
    9158        5802 :     NumericDigit *var2digits = var2->digits;
    9159             : 
    9160             :     /*
    9161             :      * First of all division by zero check; we must not be handed an
    9162             :      * unnormalized divisor.
    9163             :      */
    9164        5802 :     if (var2ndigits == 0 || var2digits[0] == 0)
    9165           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    9166             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DIVISION_BY_ZERO),
    9167             :                  errmsg("division by zero")));
    9168             : 
    9169             :     /*
    9170             :      * If the divisor has just one or two digits, delegate to div_var_int(),
    9171             :      * which uses fast short division.
    9172             :      *
    9173             :      * Similarly, on platforms with 128-bit integer support, delegate to
    9174             :      * div_var_int64() for divisors with three or four digits.
    9175             :      */
    9176        5796 :     if (var2ndigits <= 2)
    9177             :     {
    9178             :         int         idivisor;
    9179             :         int         idivisor_weight;
    9180             : 
    9181         414 :         idivisor = var2->digits[0];
    9182         414 :         idivisor_weight = var2->weight;
    9183         414 :         if (var2ndigits == 2)
    9184             :         {
    9185           0 :             idivisor = idivisor * NBASE + var2->digits[1];
    9186           0 :             idivisor_weight--;
    9187             :         }
    9188         414 :         if (var2->sign == NUMERIC_NEG)
    9189           0 :             idivisor = -idivisor;
    9190             : 
    9191         414 :         div_var_int(var1, idivisor, idivisor_weight, result, rscale, round);
    9192         414 :         return;
    9193             :     }
    9194             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
    9195        5382 :     if (var2ndigits <= 4)
    9196             :     {
    9197             :         int64       idivisor;
    9198             :         int         idivisor_weight;
    9199             : 
    9200          42 :         idivisor = var2->digits[0];
    9201          42 :         idivisor_weight = var2->weight;
    9202         150 :         for (i = 1; i < var2ndigits; i++)
    9203             :         {
    9204         108 :             idivisor = idivisor * NBASE + var2->digits[i];
    9205         108 :             idivisor_weight--;
    9206             :         }
    9207          42 :         if (var2->sign == NUMERIC_NEG)
    9208           0 :             idivisor = -idivisor;
    9209             : 
    9210          42 :         div_var_int64(var1, idivisor, idivisor_weight, result, rscale, round);
    9211          42 :         return;
    9212             :     }
    9213             : #endif
    9214             : 
    9215             :     /*
    9216             :      * Otherwise, perform full long division.
    9217             :      */
    9218             : 
    9219             :     /* Result zero check */
    9220        5340 :     if (var1ndigits == 0)
    9221             :     {
    9222          12 :         zero_var(result);
    9223          12 :         result->dscale = rscale;
    9224          12 :         return;
    9225             :     }
    9226             : 
    9227             :     /*
    9228             :      * Determine the result sign, weight and number of digits to calculate
    9229             :      */
    9230        5328 :     if (var1->sign == var2->sign)
    9231        5256 :         res_sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    9232             :     else
    9233          72 :         res_sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
    9234        5328 :     res_weight = var1->weight - var2->weight + 1;
    9235             :     /* The number of accurate result digits we need to produce: */
    9236        5328 :     div_ndigits = res_weight + 1 + (rscale + DEC_DIGITS - 1) / DEC_DIGITS;
    9237             :     /* Add guard digits for roundoff error */
    9238        5328 :     div_ndigits += DIV_GUARD_DIGITS;
    9239        5328 :     if (div_ndigits < DIV_GUARD_DIGITS)
    9240           0 :         div_ndigits = DIV_GUARD_DIGITS;
    9241             : 
    9242             :     /*
    9243             :      * We do the arithmetic in an array "div[]" of signed int's.  Since
    9244             :      * INT_MAX is noticeably larger than NBASE*NBASE, this gives us headroom
    9245             :      * to avoid normalizing carries immediately.
    9246             :      *
    9247             :      * We start with div[] containing one zero digit followed by the
    9248             :      * dividend's digits (plus appended zeroes to reach the desired precision
    9249             :      * including guard digits).  Each step of the main loop computes an
    9250             :      * (approximate) quotient digit and stores it into div[], removing one
    9251             :      * position of dividend space.  A final pass of carry propagation takes
    9252             :      * care of any mistaken quotient digits.
    9253             :      *
    9254             :      * Note that div[] doesn't necessarily contain all of the digits from the
    9255             :      * dividend --- the desired precision plus guard digits might be less than
    9256             :      * the dividend's precision.  This happens, for example, in the square
    9257             :      * root algorithm, where we typically divide a 2N-digit number by an
    9258             :      * N-digit number, and only require a result with N digits of precision.
    9259             :      */
    9260        5328 :     div = (int *) palloc0((div_ndigits + 1) * sizeof(int));
    9261        5328 :     load_ndigits = Min(div_ndigits, var1ndigits);
    9262       72708 :     for (i = 0; i < load_ndigits; i++)
    9263       67380 :         div[i + 1] = var1digits[i];
    9264             : 
    9265             :     /*
    9266             :      * We estimate each quotient digit using floating-point arithmetic, taking
    9267             :      * the first four digits of the (current) dividend and divisor.  This must
    9268             :      * be float to avoid overflow.  The quotient digits will generally be off
    9269             :      * by no more than one from the exact answer.
    9270             :      */
    9271        5328 :     fdivisor = (double) var2digits[0];
    9272       21312 :     for (i = 1; i < 4; i++)
    9273             :     {
    9274       15984 :         fdivisor *= NBASE;
    9275       15984 :         if (i < var2ndigits)
    9276       15984 :             fdivisor += (double) var2digits[i];
    9277             :     }
    9278        5328 :     fdivisorinverse = 1.0 / fdivisor;
    9279             : 
    9280             :     /*
    9281             :      * maxdiv tracks the maximum possible absolute value of any div[] entry;
    9282             :      * when this threatens to exceed INT_MAX, we take the time to propagate
    9283             :      * carries.  Furthermore, we need to ensure that overflow doesn't occur
    9284             :      * during the carry propagation passes either.  The carry values may have
    9285             :      * an absolute value as high as INT_MAX/NBASE + 1, so really we must
    9286             :      * normalize when digits threaten to exceed INT_MAX - INT_MAX/NBASE - 1.
    9287             :      *
    9288             :      * To avoid overflow in maxdiv itself, it represents the max absolute
    9289             :      * value divided by NBASE-1, ie, at the top of the loop it is known that
    9290             :      * no div[] entry has an absolute value exceeding maxdiv * (NBASE-1).
    9291             :      *
    9292             :      * Actually, though, that holds good only for div[] entries after div[qi];
    9293             :      * the adjustment done at the bottom of the loop may cause div[qi + 1] to
    9294             :      * exceed the maxdiv limit, so that div[qi] in the next iteration is
    9295             :      * beyond the limit.  This does not cause problems, as explained below.
    9296             :      */
    9297        5328 :     maxdiv = 1;
    9298             : 
    9299             :     /*
    9300             :      * Outer loop computes next quotient digit, which will go into div[qi]
    9301             :      */
    9302       90288 :     for (qi = 0; qi < div_ndigits; qi++)
    9303             :     {
    9304             :         /* Approximate the current dividend value */
    9305       84960 :         fdividend = (double) div[qi];
    9306      339840 :         for (i = 1; i < 4; i++)
    9307             :         {
    9308      254880 :             fdividend *= NBASE;
    9309      254880 :             if (qi + i <= div_ndigits)
    9310      238896 :                 fdividend += (double) div[qi + i];
    9311             :         }
    9312             :         /* Compute the (approximate) quotient digit */
    9313       84960 :         fquotient = fdividend * fdivisorinverse;
    9314       84960 :         qdigit = (fquotient >= 0.0) ? ((int) fquotient) :
    9315           6 :             (((int) fquotient) - 1);    /* truncate towards -infinity */
    9316             : 
    9317       84960 :         if (qdigit != 0)
    9318             :         {
    9319             :             /* Do we need to normalize now? */
    9320       75966 :             maxdiv += abs(qdigit);
    9321       75966 :             if (maxdiv > (INT_MAX - INT_MAX / NBASE - 1) / (NBASE - 1))
    9322             :             {
    9323             :                 /*
    9324             :                  * Yes, do it.  Note that if var2ndigits is much smaller than
    9325             :                  * div_ndigits, we can save a significant amount of effort
    9326             :                  * here by noting that we only need to normalise those div[]
    9327             :                  * entries touched where prior iterations subtracted multiples
    9328             :                  * of the divisor.
    9329             :                  */
    9330          96 :                 carry = 0;
    9331        1896 :                 for (i = Min(qi + var2ndigits - 2, div_ndigits); i > qi; i--)
    9332             :                 {
    9333        1800 :                     newdig = div[i] + carry;
    9334        1800 :                     if (newdig < 0)
    9335             :                     {
    9336        1800 :                         carry = -((-newdig - 1) / NBASE) - 1;
    9337        1800 :                         newdig -= carry * NBASE;
    9338             :                     }
    9339           0 :                     else if (newdig >= NBASE)
    9340             :                     {
    9341           0 :                         carry = newdig / NBASE;
    9342           0 :                         newdig -= carry * NBASE;
    9343             :                     }
    9344             :                     else
    9345           0 :                         carry = 0;
    9346        1800 :                     div[i] = newdig;
    9347             :                 }
    9348          96 :                 newdig = div[qi] + carry;
    9349          96 :                 div[qi] = newdig;
    9350             : 
    9351             :                 /*
    9352             :                  * All the div[] digits except possibly div[qi] are now in the
    9353             :                  * range 0..NBASE-1.  We do not need to consider div[qi] in
    9354             :                  * the maxdiv value anymore, so we can reset maxdiv to 1.
    9355             :                  */
    9356          96 :                 maxdiv = 1;
    9357             : 
    9358             :                 /*
    9359             :                  * Recompute the quotient digit since new info may have
    9360             :                  * propagated into the top four dividend digits
    9361             :                  */
    9362          96 :                 fdividend = (double) div[qi];
    9363         384 :                 for (i = 1; i < 4; i++)
    9364             :                 {
    9365         288 :                     fdividend *= NBASE;
    9366         288 :                     if (qi + i <= div_ndigits)
    9367         288 :                         fdividend += (double) div[qi + i];
    9368             :                 }
    9369             :                 /* Compute the (approximate) quotient digit */
    9370          96 :                 fquotient = fdividend * fdivisorinverse;
    9371          96 :                 qdigit = (fquotient >= 0.0) ? ((int) fquotient) :
    9372           0 :                     (((int) fquotient) - 1);    /* truncate towards -infinity */
    9373          96 :                 maxdiv += abs(qdigit);
    9374             :             }
    9375             : 
    9376             :             /*
    9377             :              * Subtract off the appropriate multiple of the divisor.
    9378             :              *
    9379             :              * The digits beyond div[qi] cannot overflow, because we know they
    9380             :              * will fall within the maxdiv limit.  As for div[qi] itself, note
    9381             :              * that qdigit is approximately trunc(div[qi] / vardigits[0]),
    9382             :              * which would make the new value simply div[qi] mod vardigits[0].
    9383             :              * The lower-order terms in qdigit can change this result by not
    9384             :              * more than about twice INT_MAX/NBASE, so overflow is impossible.
    9385             :              *
    9386             :              * This inner loop is the performance bottleneck for division, so
    9387             :              * code it in the same way as the inner loop of mul_var() so that
    9388             :              * it can be auto-vectorized.  We cast qdigit to NumericDigit
    9389             :              * before multiplying to allow the compiler to generate more
    9390             :              * efficient code (using 16-bit multiplication), which is safe
    9391             :              * since we know that the quotient digit is off by at most one, so
    9392             :              * there is no overflow risk.
    9393             :              */
    9394       75966 :             if (qdigit != 0)
    9395             :             {
    9396       75966 :                 int         istop = Min(var2ndigits, div_ndigits - qi + 1);
    9397       75966 :                 int        *div_qi = &div[qi];
    9398             : 
    9399      930036 :                 for (i = 0; i < istop; i++)
    9400      854070 :                     div_qi[i] -= ((NumericDigit) qdigit) * var2digits[i];
    9401             :             }
    9402             :         }
    9403             : 
    9404             :         /*
    9405             :          * The dividend digit we are about to replace might still be nonzero.
    9406             :          * Fold it into the next digit position.
    9407             :          *
    9408             :          * There is no risk of overflow here, although proving that requires
    9409             :          * some care.  Much as with the argument for div[qi] not overflowing,
    9410             :          * if we consider the first two terms in the numerator and denominator
    9411             :          * of qdigit, we can see that the final value of div[qi + 1] will be
    9412             :          * approximately a remainder mod (vardigits[0]*NBASE + vardigits[1]).
    9413             :          * Accounting for the lower-order terms is a bit complicated but ends
    9414             :          * up adding not much more than INT_MAX/NBASE to the possible range.
    9415             :          * Thus, div[qi + 1] cannot overflow here, and in its role as div[qi]
    9416             :          * in the next loop iteration, it can't be large enough to cause
    9417             :          * overflow in the carry propagation step (if any), either.
    9418             :          *
    9419             :          * But having said that: div[qi] can be more than INT_MAX/NBASE, as
    9420             :          * noted above, which means that the product div[qi] * NBASE *can*
    9421             :          * overflow.  When that happens, adding it to div[qi + 1] will always
    9422             :          * cause a canceling overflow so that the end result is correct.  We
    9423             :          * could avoid the intermediate overflow by doing the multiplication
    9424             :          * and addition in int64 arithmetic, but so far there appears no need.
    9425             :          */
    9426       84960 :         div[qi + 1] += div[qi] * NBASE;
    9427             : 
    9428       84960 :         div[qi] = qdigit;
    9429             :     }
    9430             : 
    9431             :     /*
    9432             :      * Approximate and store the last quotient digit (div[div_ndigits])
    9433             :      */
    9434        5328 :     fdividend = (double) div[qi];
    9435       21312 :     for (i = 1; i < 4; i++)
    9436       15984 :         fdividend *= NBASE;
    9437        5328 :     fquotient = fdividend * fdivisorinverse;
    9438        5328 :     qdigit = (fquotient >= 0.0) ? ((int) fquotient) :
    9439           0 :         (((int) fquotient) - 1);    /* truncate towards -infinity */
    9440        5328 :     div[qi] = qdigit;
    9441             : 
    9442             :     /*
    9443             :      * Because the quotient digits might be off by one, some of them might be
    9444             :      * -1 or NBASE at this point.  The represented value is correct in a
    9445             :      * mathematical sense, but it doesn't look right.  We do a final carry
    9446             :      * propagation pass to normalize the digits, which we combine with storing
    9447             :      * the result digits into the output.  Note that this is still done at
    9448             :      * full precision w/guard digits.
    9449             :      */
    9450        5328 :     alloc_var(result, div_ndigits + 1);
    9451        5328 :     res_digits = result->digits;
    9452        5328 :     carry = 0;
    9453       95616 :     for (i = div_ndigits; i >= 0; i--)
    9454             :     {
    9455       90288 :         newdig = div[i] + carry;
    9456       90288 :         if (newdig < 0)
    9457             :         {
    9458          12 :             carry = -((-newdig - 1) / NBASE) - 1;
    9459          12 :             newdig -= carry * NBASE;
    9460             :         }
    9461       90276 :         else if (newdig >= NBASE)
    9462             :         {
    9463         348 :             carry = newdig / NBASE;
    9464         348 :             newdig -= carry * NBASE;
    9465             :         }
    9466             :         else
    9467       89928 :             carry = 0;
    9468       90288 :         res_digits[i] = newdig;
    9469             :     }
    9470        5328 :     Assert(carry == 0);
    9471             : 
    9472        5328 :     pfree(div);
    9473             : 
    9474             :     /*
    9475             :      * Finally, round the result to the requested precision.
    9476             :      */
    9477        5328 :     result->weight = res_weight;
    9478        5328 :     result->sign = res_sign;
    9479             : 
    9480             :     /* Round to target rscale (and set result->dscale) */
    9481        5328 :     if (round)
    9482         810 :         round_var(result, rscale);
    9483             :     else
    9484        4518 :         trunc_var(result, rscale);
    9485             : 
    9486             :     /* Strip leading and trailing zeroes */
    9487        5328 :     strip_var(result);
    9488             : }
    9489             : 
    9490             : 
    9491             : /*
    9492             :  * div_var_int() -
    9493             :  *
    9494             :  *  Divide a numeric variable by a 32-bit integer with the specified weight.
    9495             :  *  The quotient var / (ival * NBASE^ival_weight) is stored in result.
    9496             :  */
    9497             : static void
    9498      194920 : div_var_int(const NumericVar *var, int ival, int ival_weight,
    9499             :             NumericVar *result, int rscale, bool round)
    9500             : {
    9501      194920 :     NumericDigit *var_digits = var->digits;
    9502      194920 :     int         var_ndigits = var->ndigits;
    9503             :     int         res_sign;
    9504             :     int         res_weight;
    9505             :     int         res_ndigits;
    9506             :     NumericDigit *res_buf;
    9507             :     NumericDigit *res_digits;
    9508             :     uint32      divisor;
    9509             :     int         i;
    9510             : 
    9511             :     /* Guard against division by zero */
    9512      194920 :     if (ival == 0)
    9513           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    9514             :                 errcode(ERRCODE_DIVISION_BY_ZERO),
    9515             :                 errmsg("division by zero"));
    9516             : 
    9517             :     /* Result zero check */
    9518      194920 :     if (var_ndigits == 0)
    9519             :     {
    9520        2282 :         zero_var(result);
    9521        2282 :         result->dscale = rscale;
    9522        2282 :         return;
    9523             :     }
    9524             : 
    9525             :     /*
    9526             :      * Determine the result sign, weight and number of digits to calculate.
    9527             :      * The weight figured here is correct if the emitted quotient has no
    9528             :      * leading zero digits; otherwise strip_var() will fix things up.
    9529             :      */
    9530      192638 :     if (var->sign == NUMERIC_POS)
    9531      189812 :         res_sign = ival > 0 ? NUMERIC_POS : NUMERIC_NEG;
    9532             :     else
    9533        2826 :         res_sign = ival > 0 ? NUMERIC_NEG : NUMERIC_POS;
    9534      192638 :     res_weight = var->weight - ival_weight;
    9535             :     /* The number of accurate result digits we need to produce: */
    9536      192638 :     res_ndigits = res_weight + 1 + (rscale + DEC_DIGITS - 1) / DEC_DIGITS;
    9537             :     /* ... but always at least 1 */
    9538      192638 :     res_ndigits = Max(res_ndigits, 1);
    9539             :     /* If rounding needed, figure one more digit to ensure correct result */
    9540      192638 :     if (round)
    9541      136982 :         res_ndigits++;
    9542             : 
    9543      192638 :     res_buf = digitbuf_alloc(res_ndigits + 1);
    9544      192638 :     res_buf[0] = 0;             /* spare digit for later rounding */
    9545      192638 :     res_digits = res_buf + 1;
    9546             : 
    9547             :     /*
    9548             :      * Now compute the quotient digits.  This is the short division algorithm
    9549             :      * described in Knuth volume 2, section 4.3.1 exercise 16, except that we
    9550             :      * allow the divisor to exceed the internal base.
    9551             :      *
    9552             :      * In this algorithm, the carry from one digit to the next is at most
    9553             :      * divisor - 1.  Therefore, while processing the next digit, carry may
    9554             :      * become as large as divisor * NBASE - 1, and so it requires a 64-bit
    9555             :      * integer if this exceeds UINT_MAX.
    9556             :      */
    9557      192638 :     divisor = abs(ival);
    9558             : 
    9559      192638 :     if (divisor <= UINT_MAX / NBASE)
    9560             :     {
    9561             :         /* carry cannot overflow 32 bits */
    9562      188498 :         uint32      carry = 0;
    9563             : 
    9564     1892068 :         for (i = 0; i < res_ndigits; i++)
    9565             :         {
    9566     1703570 :             carry = carry * NBASE + (i < var_ndigits ? var_digits[i] : 0);
    9567     1703570 :             res_digits[i] = (NumericDigit) (carry / divisor);
    9568     1703570 :             carry = carry % divisor;
    9569             :         }
    9570             :     }
    9571             :     else
    9572             :     {
    9573             :         /* carry may exceed 32 bits */
    9574        4140 :         uint64      carry = 0;
    9575             : 
    9576       13086 :         for (i = 0; i < res_ndigits; i++)
    9577             :         {
    9578        8946 :             carry = carry * NBASE + (i < var_ndigits ? var_digits[i] : 0);
    9579        8946 :             res_digits[i] = (NumericDigit) (carry / divisor);
    9580        8946 :             carry = carry % divisor;
    9581             :         }
    9582             :     }
    9583             : 
    9584             :     /* Store the quotient in result */
    9585      192638 :     digitbuf_free(result->buf);
    9586      192638 :     result->ndigits = res_ndigits;
    9587      192638 :     result->buf = res_buf;
    9588      192638 :     result->digits = res_digits;
    9589      192638 :     result->weight = res_weight;
    9590      192638 :     result->sign = res_sign;
    9591             : 
    9592             :     /* Round or truncate to target rscale (and set result->dscale) */
    9593      192638 :     if (round)
    9594      136982 :         round_var(result, rscale);
    9595             :     else
    9596       55656 :         trunc_var(result, rscale);
    9597             : 
    9598             :     /* Strip leading/trailing zeroes */

    9600             : }

    9720             : /*
    9721             :  * Default scale selection for division
    9722             :  *
    9723             :  * Returns the appropriate result scale for the division result.
    9724             :  */
    9725             : static int
    9726      124224 : select_div_scale(const NumericVar *var1, const NumericVar *var2)
    9727             : {
    9728             :     int         weight1,
    9729             :                 weight2,
    9730             :                 qweight,
    9731             :                 i;
    9732             :     NumericDigit firstdigit1,
    9733             :                 firstdigit2;
    9734             :     int         rscale;
    9735             : 
    9736             :     /*
    9737             :      * The result scale of a division isn't specified in any SQL standard. For
    9738             :      * PostgreSQL we select a result scale that will give at least
    9739             :      * NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS significant digits, so that numeric gives a
    9740             :      * result no less accurate than float8; but use a scale not less than
    9741             :      * either input's display scale.
    9742             :      */
    9743             : 
    9744             :     /* Get the actual (normalized) weight and first digit of each input */
    9745             : 
    9746      124224 :     weight1 = 0;                /* values to use if var1 is zero */
    9747      124224 :     firstdigit1 = 0;
    9748      124224 :     for (i = 0; i < var1->ndigits; i++)
    9749             :     {
    9750      122512 :         firstdigit1 = var1->digits[i];
    9751      122512 :         if (firstdigit1 != 0)
    9752             :         {
    9753      122512 :             weight1 = var1->weight - i;
    9754      122512 :             break;
    9755             :         }
    9756             :     }
    9757             : 
    9758      124224 :     weight2 = 0;                /* values to use if var2 is zero */
    9759      124224 :     firstdigit2 = 0;
    9760      124224 :     for (i = 0; i < var2->ndigits; i++)
    9761             :     {
    9762      124174 :         firstdigit2 = var2->digits[i];
    9763      124174 :         if (firstdigit2 != 0)
    9764             :         {
    9765      124174 :             weight2 = var2->weight - i;
    9766      124174 :             break;
    9767             :         }
    9768             :     }
    9769             : 
    9770             :     /*
    9771             :      * Estimate weight of quotient.  If the two first digits are equal, we
    9772             :      * can't be sure, but assume that var1 is less than var2.
    9773             :      */
    9774      124224 :     qweight = weight1 - weight2;
    9775      124224 :     if (firstdigit1 <= firstdigit2)
    9776      112432 :         qweight--;
    9777             : 
    9778             :     /* Select result scale */
    9779      124224 :     rscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS - qweight * DEC_DIGITS;
    9780      124224 :     rscale = Max(rscale, var1->dscale);
    9781      124224 :     rscale = Max(rscale, var2->dscale);
    9782      124224 :     rscale = Max(rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
    9783      124224 :     rscale = Min(rscale, NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE);
    9784             : 
    9785      124224 :     return rscale;
    9786             : }

    9790             :  * mod_var() -
    9791             :  *

    9794             : static void
    9795       54606 : mod_var(const NumericVar *var1, const NumericVar *var2, NumericVar *result)
    9796             : {

    9801             :     /* ---------
    9802             :      * We do this using the equation
    9803             :      *      mod(x,y) = x - trunc(x/y)*y
    9804             :      * div_var can be persuaded to give us trunc(x/y) directly.

    9808             :

    9817             : /*
    9818             :  * div_mod_var() -

    9821             :  *  numeric variables.  The remainder is precise to var2's dscale.

    9823             : static void

    9935             : /*
    9936             :  * gcd_var() -
    9937             :  *
    9938             :  *  Calculate the greatest common divisor of two numerics at variable level
    9939             :  */
    9940             : static void
    9941         222 : gcd_var(const NumericVar *var1, const NumericVar *var2, NumericVar *result)
    9942             : {
    9943             :     int         res_dscale;
    9944             :     int         cmp;
    9945             :     NumericVar  tmp_arg;
    9946             :     NumericVar  mod;
    9947             : 
    9948         222 :     res_dscale = Max(var1->dscale, var2->dscale);
    9949             : 
    9950             :     /*
    9951             :      * Arrange for var1 to be the number with the greater absolute value.
    9952             :      *
    9953             :      * This would happen automatically in the loop below, but avoids an
    9954             :      * expensive modulo operation.
    9955             :      */
    9956         222 :     cmp = cmp_abs(var1, var2);
    9957         222 :     if (cmp < 0)
    9958             :     {
    9959          84 :         const NumericVar *tmp = var1;
    9960             : 
    9961          84 :         var1 = var2;
    9962          84 :         var2 = tmp;
    9963             :     }
    9964             : 
    9965             :     /*
    9966             :      * Also avoid the taking the modulo if the inputs have the same absolute
    9967             :      * value, or if the smaller input is zero.
    9968             :      */
    9969         222 :     if (cmp == 0 || var2->ndigits == 0)
    9970             :     {
    9971          72 :         set_var_from_var(var1, result);
    9972          72 :         result->sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    9973          72 :         result->dscale = res_dscale;
    9974          72 :         return;
    9975             :     }
    9976             : 
    9977         150 :     init_var(&tmp_arg);
    9978         150 :     init_var(&mod);
    9979             : 
    9980             :     /* Use the Euclidean algorithm to find the GCD */
    9981         150 :     set_var_from_var(var1, &tmp_arg);
    9982         150 :     set_var_from_var(var2, result);
    9983             : 
    9984             :     for (;;)
    9985             :     {
    9986             :         /* this loop can take a while, so allow it to be interrupted */
    9987         588 :         CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    9988             : 
    9989         588 :         mod_var(&tmp_arg, result, &mod);
    9990         588 :         if (mod.ndigits == 0)
    9991         150 :             break;
    9992         438 :         set_var_from_var(result, &tmp_arg);
    9993         438 :         set_var_from_var(&mod, result);
    9994             :     }
    9995         150 :     result->sign = NUMERIC_POS;
    9996         150 :     result->dscale = res_dscale;
    9997             : 
    9998         150 :     free_var(&tmp_arg);
    9999         150 :     free_var(&mod);
   10000             : }
   10001             : 
   10002             : 
   10003             : /*
   10004             :  * sqrt_var() -
   10005             :  *
   10006             :  *  Compute the square root of x using the Karatsuba Square Root algorithm.
   10007             :  *  NOTE: we allow rscale < 0 here, implying rounding before the decimal
   10008             :  *  point.
   10009             :  */
   10010             : static void
   10011        4194 : sqrt_var(const NumericVar *arg, NumericVar *result, int rscale)
   10012             : {
   10013             :     int         stat;
   10014             :     int         res_weight;
   10015             :     int         res_ndigits;
   10016             :     int         src_ndigits;
   10017             :     int         step;
   10018             :     int         ndigits[32];
   10019             :     int         blen;
   10020             :     int64       arg_int64;
   10021             :     int         src_idx;
   10022             :     int64       s_int64;
   10023             :     int64       r_int64;
   10024             :     NumericVar  s_var;
   10025             :     NumericVar  r_var;
   10026             :     NumericVar  a0_var;
   10027             :     NumericVar  a1_var;
   10028             :     NumericVar  q_var;
   10029             :     NumericVar  u_var;
   10030             : 
   10031        4194 :     stat = cmp_var(arg, &const_zero);
   10032        4194 :     if (stat == 0)
   10033             :     {
   10034          18 :         zero_var(result);
   10035          18 :         result->dscale = rscale;
   10036          18 :         return;
   10037             :     }
   10038             : 
   10039             :     /*
   10040             :      * SQL2003 defines sqrt() in terms of power, so we need to emit the right
   10041             :      * SQLSTATE error code if the operand is negative.
   10042             :      */
   10043        4176 :     if (stat < 0)
   10044           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10045             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
   10046             :                  errmsg("cannot take square root of a negative number")));
   10047             : 
   10048        4170 :     init_var(&s_var);
   10049        4170 :     init_var(&r_var);
   10050        4170 :     init_var(&a0_var);
   10051        4170 :     init_var(&a1_var);
   10052        4170 :     init_var(&q_var);
   10053        4170 :     init_var(&u_var);
   10054             : 
   10055             :     /*
   10056             :      * The result weight is half the input weight, rounded towards minus
   10057             :      * infinity --- res_weight = floor(arg->weight / 2).
   10058             :      */
   10059        4170 :     if (arg->weight >= 0)
   10060        3858 :         res_weight = arg->weight / 2;
   10061             :     else
   10062         312 :         res_weight = -((-arg->weight - 1) / 2 + 1);
   10063             : 
   10064             :     /*
   10065             :      * Number of NBASE digits to compute.  To ensure correct rounding, compute
   10066             :      * at least 1 extra decimal digit.  We explicitly allow rscale to be
   10067             :      * negative here, but must always compute at least 1 NBASE digit.  Thus
   10068             :      * res_ndigits = res_weight + 1 + ceil((rscale + 1) / DEC_DIGITS) or 1.
   10069             :      */
   10070        4170 :     if (rscale + 1 >= 0)
   10071        4170 :         res_ndigits = res_weight + 1 + (rscale + DEC_DIGITS) / DEC_DIGITS;
   10072             :     else
   10073           0 :         res_ndigits = res_weight + 1 - (-rscale - 1) / DEC_DIGITS;
   10074        4170 :     res_ndigits = Max(res_ndigits, 1);
   10075             : 
   10076             :     /*
   10077             :      * Number of source NBASE digits logically required to produce a result
   10078             :      * with this precision --- every digit before the decimal point, plus 2
   10079             :      * for each result digit after the decimal point (or minus 2 for each
   10080             :      * result digit we round before the decimal point).
   10081             :      */
   10082        4170 :     src_ndigits = arg->weight + 1 + (res_ndigits - res_weight - 1) * 2;
   10083        4170 :     src_ndigits = Max(src_ndigits, 1);
   10084             : 
   10085             :     /* ----------
   10086             :      * From this point on, we treat the input and the result as integers and
   10087             :      * compute the integer square root and remainder using the Karatsuba
   10088             :      * Square Root algorithm, which may be written recursively as follows:
   10089             :      *
   10090             :      *  SqrtRem(n = a3*b^3 + a2*b^2 + a1*b + a0):
   10091             :      *      [ for some base b, and coefficients a0,a1,a2,a3 chosen so that
   10092             :      *        0 <= a0,a1,a2 < b and a3 >= b/4 ]
   10093             :      *      Let (s,r) = SqrtRem(a3*b + a2)
   10094             :      *      Let (q,u) = DivRem(r*b + a1, 2*s)
   10095             :      *      Let s = s*b + q
   10096             :      *      Let r = u*b + a0 - q^2
   10097             :      *      If r < 0 Then
   10098             :      *          Let r = r + s
   10099             :      *          Let s = s - 1
   10100             :      *          Let r = r + s
   10101             :      *      Return (s,r)
   10102             :      *
   10103             :      * See "Karatsuba Square Root", Paul Zimmermann, INRIA Research Report
   10104             :      * RR-3805, November 1999.  At the time of writing this was available
   10105             :      * on the net at <https://hal.inria.fr/inria-00072854>.
   10106             :      *
   10107             :      * The way to read the assumption "n = a3*b^3 + a2*b^2 + a1*b + a0" is
   10108             :      * "choose a base b such that n requires at least four base-b digits to
   10109             :      * express; then those digits are a3,a2,a1,a0, with a3 possibly larger
   10110             :      * than b".  For optimal performance, b should have approximately a
   10111             :      * quarter the number of digits in the input, so that the outer square
   10112             :      * root computes roughly twice as many digits as the inner one.  For
   10113             :      * simplicity, we choose b = NBASE^blen, an integer power of NBASE.
   10114             :      *
   10115             :      * We implement the algorithm iteratively rather than recursively, to
   10116             :      * allow the working variables to be reused.  With this approach, each
   10117             :      * digit of the input is read precisely once --- src_idx tracks the number
   10118             :      * of input digits used so far.
   10119             :      *
   10120             :      * The array ndigits[] holds the number of NBASE digits of the input that
   10121             :      * will have been used at the end of each iteration, which roughly doubles
   10122             :      * each time.  Note that the array elements are stored in reverse order,
   10123             :      * so if the final iteration requires src_ndigits = 37 input digits, the
   10124             :      * array will contain [37,19,11,7,5,3], and we would start by computing
   10125             :      * the square root of the 3 most significant NBASE digits.
   10126             :      *
   10127             :      * In each iteration, we choose blen to be the largest integer for which
   10128             :      * the input number has a3 >= b/4, when written in the form above.  In
   10129             :      * general, this means blen = src_ndigits / 4 (truncated), but if
   10130             :      * src_ndigits is a multiple of 4, that might lead to the coefficient a3
   10131             :      * being less than b/4 (if the first input digit is less than NBASE/4), in
   10132             :      * which case we choose blen = src_ndigits / 4 - 1.  The number of digits
   10133             :      * in the inner square root is then src_ndigits - 2*blen.  So, for
   10134             :      * example, if we have src_ndigits = 26 initially, the array ndigits[]
   10135             :      * will be either [26,14,8,4] or [26,14,8,6,4], depending on the size of
   10136             :      * the first input digit.
   10137             :      *
   10138             :      * Additionally, we can put an upper bound on the number of steps required
   10139             :      * as follows --- suppose that the number of source digits is an n-bit
   10140             :      * number in the range [2^(n-1), 2^n-1], then blen will be in the range
   10141             :      * [2^(n-3)-1, 2^(n-2)-1] and the number of digits in the inner square
   10142             :      * root will be in the range [2^(n-2), 2^(n-1)+1].  In the next step, blen
   10143             :      * will be in the range [2^(n-4)-1, 2^(n-3)] and the number of digits in
   10144             :      * the next inner square root will be in the range [2^(n-3), 2^(n-2)+1].
   10145             :      * This pattern repeats, and in the worst case the array ndigits[] will
   10146             :      * contain [2^n-1, 2^(n-1)+1, 2^(n-2)+1, ... 9, 5, 3], and the computation
   10147             :      * will require n steps.  Therefore, since all digit array sizes are
   10148             :      * signed 32-bit integers, the number of steps required is guaranteed to
   10149             :      * be less than 32.
   10150             :      * ----------
   10151             :      */
   10152        4170 :     step = 0;
   10153       19962 :     while ((ndigits[step] = src_ndigits) > 4)
   10154             :     {
   10155             :         /* Choose b so that a3 >= b/4, as described above */
   10156       15792 :         blen = src_ndigits / 4;
   10157       15792 :         if (blen * 4 == src_ndigits && arg->digits[0] < NBASE / 4)
   10158         324 :             blen--;
   10159             : 
   10160             :         /* Number of digits in the next step (inner square root) */
   10161       15792 :         src_ndigits -= 2 * blen;
   10162       15792 :         step++;
   10163             :     }
   10164             : 
   10165             :     /*
   10166             :      * First iteration (innermost square root and remainder):
   10167             :      *
   10168             :      * Here src_ndigits <= 4, and the input fits in an int64.  Its square root
   10169             :      * has at most 9 decimal digits, so estimate it using double precision
   10170             :      * arithmetic, which will in fact almost certainly return the correct
   10171             :      * result with no further correction required.
   10172             :      */
   10173        4170 :     arg_int64 = arg->digits[0];
   10174       13314 :     for (src_idx = 1; src_idx < src_ndigits; src_idx++)
   10175             :     {
   10176        9144 :         arg_int64 *= NBASE;
   10177        9144 :         if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10178        7686 :             arg_int64 += arg->digits[src_idx];
   10179             :     }
   10180             : 
   10181        4170 :     s_int64 = (int64) sqrt((double) arg_int64);
   10182        4170 :     r_int64 = arg_int64 - s_int64 * s_int64;
   10183             : 
   10184             :     /*
   10185             :      * Use Newton's method to correct the result, if necessary.
   10186             :      *
   10187             :      * This uses integer division with truncation to compute the truncated
   10188             :      * integer square root by iterating using the formula x -> (x + n/x) / 2.
   10189             :      * This is known to converge to isqrt(n), unless n+1 is a perfect square.
   10190             :      * If n+1 is a perfect square, the sequence will oscillate between the two
   10191             :      * values isqrt(n) and isqrt(n)+1, so we can be assured of convergence by
   10192             :      * checking the remainder.
   10193             :      */
   10194        4170 :     while (r_int64 < 0 || r_int64 > 2 * s_int64)
   10195             :     {
   10196           0 :         s_int64 = (s_int64 + arg_int64 / s_int64) / 2;
   10197           0 :         r_int64 = arg_int64 - s_int64 * s_int64;
   10198             :     }
   10199             : 
   10200             :     /*
   10201             :      * Iterations with src_ndigits <= 8:
   10202             :      *
   10203             :      * The next 1 or 2 iterations compute larger (outer) square roots with
   10204             :      * src_ndigits <= 8, so the result still fits in an int64 (even though the
   10205             :      * input no longer does) and we can continue to compute using int64
   10206             :      * variables to avoid more expensive numeric computations.
   10207             :      *
   10208             :      * It is fairly easy to see that there is no risk of the intermediate
   10209             :      * values below overflowing 64-bit integers.  In the worst case, the
   10210             :      * previous iteration will have computed a 3-digit square root (of a
   10211             :      * 6-digit input less than NBASE^6 / 4), so at the start of this
   10212             :      * iteration, s will be less than NBASE^3 / 2 = 10^12 / 2, and r will be
   10213             :      * less than 10^12.  In this case, blen will be 1, so numer will be less
   10214             :      * than 10^17, and denom will be less than 10^12 (and hence u will also be
   10215             :      * less than 10^12).  Finally, since q^2 = u*b + a0 - r, we can also be
   10216             :      * sure that q^2 < 10^17.  Therefore all these quantities fit comfortably
   10217             :      * in 64-bit integers.
   10218             :      */
   10219        4170 :     step--;
   10220       10566 :     while (step >= 0 && (src_ndigits = ndigits[step]) <= 8)
   10221             :     {
   10222             :         int         b;
   10223             :         int         a0;
   10224             :         int         a1;
   10225             :         int         i;
   10226             :         int64       numer;
   10227             :         int64       denom;
   10228             :         int64       q;
   10229             :         int64       u;
   10230             : 
   10231        6396 :         blen = (src_ndigits - src_idx) / 2;
   10232             : 
   10233             :         /* Extract a1 and a0, and compute b */
   10234        6396 :         a0 = 0;
   10235        6396 :         a1 = 0;
   10236        6396 :         b = 1;
   10237             : 
   10238       12936 :         for (i = 0; i < blen; i++, src_idx++)
   10239             :         {
   10240        6540 :             b *= NBASE;
   10241        6540 :             a1 *= NBASE;
   10242        6540 :             if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10243        4800 :                 a1 += arg->digits[src_idx];
   10244             :         }
   10245             : 
   10246       12936 :         for (i = 0; i < blen; i++, src_idx++)
   10247             :         {
   10248        6540 :             a0 *= NBASE;
   10249        6540 :             if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10250        4644 :                 a0 += arg->digits[src_idx];
   10251             :         }
   10252             : 
   10253             :         /* Compute (q,u) = DivRem(r*b + a1, 2*s) */
   10254        6396 :         numer = r_int64 * b + a1;
   10255        6396 :         denom = 2 * s_int64;
   10256        6396 :         q = numer / denom;
   10257        6396 :         u = numer - q * denom;
   10258             : 
   10259             :         /* Compute s = s*b + q and r = u*b + a0 - q^2 */
   10260        6396 :         s_int64 = s_int64 * b + q;
   10261        6396 :         r_int64 = u * b + a0 - q * q;
   10262             : 
   10263        6396 :         if (r_int64 < 0)
   10264             :         {
   10265             :             /* s is too large by 1; set r += s, s--, r += s */
   10266         210 :             r_int64 += s_int64;
   10267         210 :             s_int64--;
   10268         210 :             r_int64 += s_int64;
   10269             :         }
   10270             : 
   10271        6396 :         Assert(src_idx == src_ndigits); /* All input digits consumed */
   10272        6396 :         step--;
   10273             :     }
   10274             : 
   10275             :     /*
   10276             :      * On platforms with 128-bit integer support, we can further delay the
   10277             :      * need to use numeric variables.
   10278             :      */
   10279             : #ifdef HAVE_INT128
   10280        4170 :     if (step >= 0)
   10281             :     {
   10282             :         int128      s_int128;
   10283             :         int128      r_int128;
   10284             : 
   10285        4170 :         s_int128 = s_int64;
   10286        4170 :         r_int128 = r_int64;
   10287             : 
   10288             :         /*
   10289             :          * Iterations with src_ndigits <= 16:
   10290             :          *
   10291             :          * The result fits in an int128 (even though the input doesn't) so we
   10292             :          * use int128 variables to avoid more expensive numeric computations.
   10293             :          */
   10294        9048 :         while (step >= 0 && (src_ndigits = ndigits[step]) <= 16)
   10295             :         {
   10296             :             int64       b;
   10297             :             int64       a0;
   10298             :             int64       a1;
   10299             :             int64       i;
   10300             :             int128      numer;
   10301             :             int128      denom;
   10302             :             int128      q;
   10303             :             int128      u;
   10304             : 
   10305        4878 :             blen = (src_ndigits - src_idx) / 2;
   10306             : 
   10307             :             /* Extract a1 and a0, and compute b */
   10308        4878 :             a0 = 0;
   10309        4878 :             a1 = 0;
   10310        4878 :             b = 1;
   10311             : 
   10312       16080 :             for (i = 0; i < blen; i++, src_idx++)
   10313             :             {
   10314       11202 :                 b *= NBASE;
   10315       11202 :                 a1 *= NBASE;
   10316       11202 :                 if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10317        6606 :                     a1 += arg->digits[src_idx];
   10318             :             }
   10319             : 
   10320       16080 :             for (i = 0; i < blen; i++, src_idx++)
   10321             :             {
   10322       11202 :                 a0 *= NBASE;
   10323       11202 :                 if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10324        4470 :                     a0 += arg->digits[src_idx];
   10325             :             }
   10326             : 
   10327             :             /* Compute (q,u) = DivRem(r*b + a1, 2*s) */
   10328        4878 :             numer = r_int128 * b + a1;
   10329        4878 :             denom = 2 * s_int128;
   10330        4878 :             q = numer / denom;
   10331        4878 :             u = numer - q * denom;
   10332             : 
   10333             :             /* Compute s = s*b + q and r = u*b + a0 - q^2 */
   10334        4878 :             s_int128 = s_int128 * b + q;
   10335        4878 :             r_int128 = u * b + a0 - q * q;
   10336             : 
   10337        4878 :             if (r_int128 < 0)
   10338             :             {
   10339             :                 /* s is too large by 1; set r += s, s--, r += s */
   10340         192 :                 r_int128 += s_int128;

   10342         192 :                 r_int128 += s_int128;
   10343             :             }
   10344             :

   10348             : 
   10349             :         /*

   10352             :          * iteration we don't need the remainder, so we can save a few cycles
   10353             :          * there by not fully computing it.
   10354             :          */
   10355        4170 :         int128_to_numericvar(s_int128, &s_var);
   10356        4170 :         if (step >= 0)
   10357        2724 :             int128_to_numericvar(r_int128, &r_var);
   10358             :     }
   10359             :     else
   10360             :     {
   10361           0 :         int64_to_numericvar(s_int64, &s_var);
   10362             :         /* step < 0, so we certainly don't need r */
   10363             :     }
   10364             : #else                           /* !HAVE_INT128 */
   10365             :     int64_to_numericvar(s_int64, &s_var);
   10366             :     if (step >= 0)
   10367             :         int64_to_numericvar(r_int64, &r_var);
   10368             : #endif                          /* HAVE_INT128 */
   10369             : 
   10370             :     /*
   10371             :      * The remaining iterations with src_ndigits > 8 (or 16, if have int128)
   10372             :      * use numeric variables.
   10373             :      */
   10374        8688 :     while (step >= 0)
   10375             :     {
   10376             :         int         tmp_len;
   10377             : 
   10378        4518 :         src_ndigits = ndigits[step];
   10379        4518 :         blen = (src_ndigits - src_idx) / 2;
   10380             : 
   10381             :         /* Extract a1 and a0 */
   10382        4518 :         if (src_idx < arg->ndigits)
   10383             :         {
   10384        1512 :             tmp_len = Min(blen, arg->ndigits - src_idx);
   10385        1512 :             alloc_var(&a1_var, tmp_len);
   10386        1512 :             memcpy(a1_var.digits, arg->digits + src_idx,

   10420        4518 :         q_var.weight += blen;
   10421        4518 :         add_var(&q_var, &a1_var, &q_var);
   10422        4518 :         add_var(&s_var, &s_var, &u_var);
   10423        4518 :         div_mod_var(&q_var, &u_var, &q_var, &u_var);
   10424             : 
   10425             :         /* Compute s = s*b + q */
   10426        4518 :         s_var.weight += blen;
   10427        4518 :         add_var(&s_var, &q_var, &s_var);
   10428             : 
   10429             :         /*
   10430             :          * Compute r = u*b + a0 - q^2.
   10431             :          *
   10432             :          * In the final iteration, we don't actually need r; we just need to
   10433             :          * know whether it is negative, so that we know whether to adjust s.
   10434             :          * So instead of the final subtraction we can just compare.
   10435             :          */
   10436        4518 :         u_var.weight += blen;
   10437        4518 :         add_var(&u_var, &a0_var, &u_var);
   10438        4518 :         mul_var(&q_var, &q_var, &q_var, 0);
   10439             : 
   10440        4518 :         if (step > 0)
   10441             :         {
   10442             :             /* Need r for later iterations */
   10443        1794 :             sub_var(&u_var, &q_var, &r_var);
   10444        1794 :             if (r_var.sign == NUMERIC_NEG)
   10445             :             {
   10446             :                 /* s is too large by 1; set r += s, s--, r += s */
   10447         120 :                 add_var(&r_var, &s_var, &r_var);
   10448         120 :                 sub_var(&s_var, &const_one, &s_var);
   10449         120 :                 add_var(&r_var, &s_var, &r_var);
   10450             :             }
   10451             :         }
   10452             :         else
   10453             :         {
   10454             :             /* Don't need r anymore, except to test if s is too large by 1 */
   10455        2724 :             if (cmp_var(&u_var, &q_var) < 0)
   10456          36 :                 sub_var(&s_var, &const_one, &s_var);
   10457             :         }
   10458             : 
   10459        4518 :         Assert(src_idx == src_ndigits); /* All input digits consumed */
   10460        4518 :         step--;
   10461             :     }
   10462             : 
   10463             :     /*
   10464             :      * Construct the final result, rounding it to the requested precision.
   10465             :      */
   10466        4170 :     set_var_from_var(&s_var, result);
   10467        4170 :     result->weight = res_weight;
   10468        4170 :     result->sign = NUMERIC_POS;
   10469             : 
   10470             :     /* Round to target rscale (and set result->dscale) */
   10471        4170 :     round_var(result, rscale);
   10472             : 
   10473             :     /* Strip leading and trailing zeroes */
   10474        4170 :     strip_var(result);
   10475             : 
   10476        4170 :     free_var(&s_var);
   10477        4170 :     free_var(&r_var);

   10481        4170 :     free_var(&u_var);
