   10484             : 
   10485             : /*
   10486             :  * exp_var() -
   10487             :  *
   10488             :  *  Raise e to the power of x, computed to rscale fractional digits
   10489             :  */
   10490             : static void
   10491         180 : exp_var(const NumericVar *arg, NumericVar *result, int rscale)
   10492             : {
   10493             :     NumericVar  x;
   10494             :     NumericVar  elem;
   10495             :     int         ni;
   10496             :     double      val;
   10497             :     int         dweight;
   10498             :     int         ndiv2;
   10499             :     int         sig_digits;
   10500             :     int         local_rscale;
   10501             : 
   10502         180 :     init_var(&x);
   10503         180 :     init_var(&elem);
   10504             : 
   10505         180 :     set_var_from_var(arg, &x);
   10506             : 
   10507             :     /*
   10508             :      * Estimate the dweight of the result using floating point arithmetic, so
   10509             :      * that we can choose an appropriate local rscale for the calculation.
   10510             :      */
   10511         180 :     val = numericvar_to_double_no_overflow(&x);
   10512             : 
   10513             :     /* Guard against overflow/underflow */
   10514             :     /* If you change this limit, see also power_var()'s limit */
   10515         180 :     if (fabs(val) >= NUMERIC_MAX_RESULT_SCALE * 3)
   10516             :     {
   10517           6 :         if (val > 0)
   10518           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   10519             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_NUMERIC_VALUE_OUT_OF_RANGE),
   10520             :                      errmsg("value overflows numeric format")));
   10521           6 :         zero_var(result);
   10522           6 :         result->dscale = rscale;
   10523           6 :         return;
   10524             :     }
   10525             : 
   10526             :     /* decimal weight = log10(e^x) = x * log10(e) */
   10527         174 :     dweight = (int) (val * 0.434294481903252);
   10528             : 
   10529             :     /*
   10530             :      * Reduce x to the range -0.01 <= x <= 0.01 (approximately) by dividing by
   10531             :      * 2^ndiv2, to improve the convergence rate of the Taylor series.
   10532             :      *
   10533             :      * Note that the overflow check above ensures that fabs(x) < 6000, which
   10534             :      * means that ndiv2 <= 20 here.
   10535             :      */
   10536         174 :     if (fabs(val) > 0.01)
   10537             :     {
   10538         144 :         ndiv2 = 1;
   10539         144 :         val /= 2;
   10540             : 
   10541        1818 :         while (fabs(val) > 0.01)
   10542             :         {
   10543        1674 :             ndiv2++;
   10544        1674 :             val /= 2;
   10545             :         }
   10546             : 
   10547         144 :         local_rscale = x.dscale + ndiv2;
   10548         144 :         div_var_int(&x, 1 << ndiv2, 0, &x, local_rscale, true);
   10549             :     }
   10550             :     else
   10551          30 :         ndiv2 = 0;
   10552             : 
   10553             :     /*
   10554             :      * Set the scale for the Taylor series expansion.  The final result has
   10555             :      * (dweight + rscale + 1) significant digits.  In addition, we have to
   10556             :      * raise the Taylor series result to the power 2^ndiv2, which introduces
   10557             :      * an error of up to around log10(2^ndiv2) digits, so work with this many
   10558             :      * extra digits of precision (plus a few more for good measure).
   10559             :      */
   10560         174 :     sig_digits = 1 + dweight + rscale + (int) (ndiv2 * 0.301029995663981);
   10561         174 :     sig_digits = Max(sig_digits, 0) + 8;
   10562             : 
   10563         174 :     local_rscale = sig_digits - 1;
   10564             : 
   10565             :     /*
   10566             :      * Use the Taylor series
   10567             :      *
   10568             :      * exp(x) = 1 + x + x^2/2! + x^3/3! + ...
   10569             :      *
   10570             :      * Given the limited range of x, this should converge reasonably quickly.
   10571             :      * We run the series until the terms fall below the local_rscale limit.
   10572             :      */
   10573         174 :     add_var(&const_one, &x, result);
   10574             : 
   10575         174 :     mul_var(&x, &x, &elem, local_rscale);
   10576         174 :     ni = 2;
   10577         174 :     div_var_int(&elem, ni, 0, &elem, local_rscale, true);
   10578             : 
   10579        4992 :     while (elem.ndigits != 0)
   10580             :     {
   10581        4818 :         add_var(result, &elem, result);
   10582             : 
   10583        4818 :         mul_var(&elem, &x, &elem, local_rscale);
   10584        4818 :         ni++;
   10585        4818 :         div_var_int(&elem, ni, 0, &elem, local_rscale, true);
   10586             :     }
   10587             : 
   10588             :     /*
   10589             :      * Compensate for the argument range reduction.  Since the weight of the
   10590             :      * result doubles with each multiplication, we can reduce the local rscale
   10591             :      * as we proceed.
   10592             :      */
   10593        1992 :     while (ndiv2-- > 0)
   10594             :     {
   10595        1818 :         local_rscale = sig_digits - result->weight * 2 * DEC_DIGITS;
   10596        1818 :         local_rscale = Max(local_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10597        1818 :         mul_var(result, result, result, local_rscale);
   10598             :     }
   10599             : 
   10600             :     /* Round to requested rscale */
   10601         174 :     round_var(result, rscale);
   10602             : 
   10603         174 :     free_var(&x);
   10604         174 :     free_var(&elem);
   10605             : }
   10606             : 
   10607             : 
   10608             : /*
   10609             :  * Estimate the dweight of the most significant decimal digit of the natural
   10610             :  * logarithm of a number.
   10611             :  *
   10612             :  * Essentially, we're approximating log10(abs(ln(var))).  This is used to
   10613             :  * determine the appropriate rscale when computing natural logarithms.
   10614             :  *
   10615             :  * Note: many callers call this before range-checking the input.  Therefore,
   10616             :  * we must be robust against values that are invalid to apply ln() to.
   10617             :  * We don't wish to throw an error here, so just return zero in such cases.
   10618             :  */
   10619             : static int
   10620         738 : estimate_ln_dweight(const NumericVar *var)
   10621             : {
   10622             :     int         ln_dweight;
   10623             : 
   10624             :     /* Caller should fail on ln(negative), but for the moment return zero */
   10625         738 :     if (var->sign != NUMERIC_POS)
   10626          42 :         return 0;
   10627             : 
   10628        1314 :     if (cmp_var(var, &const_zero_point_nine) >= 0 &&
   10629         618 :         cmp_var(var, &const_one_point_one) <= 0)
   10630          90 :     {
   10631             :         /*
   10632             :          * 0.9 <= var <= 1.1
   10633             :          *
   10634             :          * ln(var) has a negative weight (possibly very large).  To get a
   10635             :          * reasonably accurate result, estimate it using ln(1+x) ~= x.
   10636             :          */
   10637             :         NumericVar  x;
   10638             : 
   10639          90 :         init_var(&x);
   10640          90 :         sub_var(var, &const_one, &x);
   10641             : 
   10642          90 :         if (x.ndigits > 0)
   10643             :         {
   10644             :             /* Use weight of most significant decimal digit of x */
   10645          42 :             ln_dweight = x.weight * DEC_DIGITS + (int) log10(x.digits[0]);
   10646             :         }
   10647             :         else
   10648             :         {
   10649             :             /* x = 0.  Since ln(1) = 0 exactly, we don't need extra digits */
   10650          48 :             ln_dweight = 0;
   10651             :         }
   10652             : 
   10653          90 :         free_var(&x);
   10654             :     }
   10655             :     else
   10656             :     {
   10657             :         /*
   10658             :          * Estimate the logarithm using the first couple of digits from the
   10659             :          * input number.  This will give an accurate result whenever the input
   10660             :          * is not too close to 1.
   10661             :          */
   10662         606 :         if (var->ndigits > 0)
   10663             :         {
   10664             :             int         digits;
   10665             :             int         dweight;
   10666             :             double      ln_var;
   10667             : 
   10668         564 :             digits = var->digits[0];
   10669         564 :             dweight = var->weight * DEC_DIGITS;
   10670             : 
   10671         564 :             if (var->ndigits > 1)
   10672             :             {
   10673         342 :                 digits = digits * NBASE + var->digits[1];
   10674         342 :                 dweight -= DEC_DIGITS;
   10675             :             }
   10676             : 
   10677             :             /*----------
   10678             :              * We have var ~= digits * 10^dweight
   10679             :              * so ln(var) ~= ln(digits) + dweight * ln(10)
   10680             :              *----------
   10681             :              */
   10682         564 :             ln_var = log((double) digits) + dweight * 2.302585092994046;
   10683         564 :             ln_dweight = (int) log10(fabs(ln_var));
   10684             :         }
   10685             :         else
   10686             :         {
   10687             :             /* Caller should fail on ln(0), but for the moment return zero */
   10688          42 :             ln_dweight = 0;
   10689             :         }
   10690             :     }
   10691             : 
   10692         696 :     return ln_dweight;
   10693             : }
   10694             : 
   10695             : 
   10696             : /*
   10697             :  * ln_var() -
   10698             :  *
   10699             :  *  Compute the natural log of x
   10700             :  */
   10701             : static void
   10702         834 : ln_var(const NumericVar *arg, NumericVar *result, int rscale)
   10703             : {
   10704             :     NumericVar  x;
   10705             :     NumericVar  xx;
   10706             :     int         ni;
   10707             :     NumericVar  elem;
   10708             :     NumericVar  fact;
   10709             :     int         nsqrt;
   10710             :     int         local_rscale;
   10711             :     int         cmp;
   10712             : 
   10713         834 :     cmp = cmp_var(arg, &const_zero);
   10714         834 :     if (cmp == 0)
   10715          42 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10716             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_LOG),
   10717             :                  errmsg("cannot take logarithm of zero")));
   10718         792 :     else if (cmp < 0)
   10719          36 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10720             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_LOG),
   10721             :                  errmsg("cannot take logarithm of a negative number")));
   10722             : 
   10723         756 :     init_var(&x);
   10724         756 :     init_var(&xx);
   10725         756 :     init_var(&elem);
   10726         756 :     init_var(&fact);
   10727             : 
   10728         756 :     set_var_from_var(arg, &x);
   10729         756 :     set_var_from_var(&const_two, &fact);
   10730             : 
   10731             :     /*
   10732             :      * Reduce input into range 0.9 < x < 1.1 with repeated sqrt() operations.
   10733             :      *
   10734             :      * The final logarithm will have up to around rscale+6 significant digits.
   10735             :      * Each sqrt() will roughly halve the weight of x, so adjust the local
   10736             :      * rscale as we work so that we keep this many significant digits at each
   10737             :      * step (plus a few more for good measure).
   10738             :      *
   10739             :      * Note that we allow local_rscale < 0 during this input reduction
   10740             :      * process, which implies rounding before the decimal point.  sqrt_var()
   10741             :      * explicitly supports this, and it significantly reduces the work
   10742             :      * required to reduce very large inputs to the required range.  Once the
   10743             :      * input reduction is complete, x.weight will be 0 and its display scale
   10744             :      * will be non-negative again.
   10745             :      */
   10746         756 :     nsqrt = 0;
   10747        1068 :     while (cmp_var(&x, &const_zero_point_nine) <= 0)
   10748             :     {
   10749         312 :         local_rscale = rscale - x.weight * DEC_DIGITS / 2 + 8;
   10750         312 :         sqrt_var(&x, &x, local_rscale);
   10751         312 :         mul_var(&fact, &const_two, &fact, 0);
   10752         312 :         nsqrt++;
   10753             :     }
   10754        4128 :     while (cmp_var(&x, &const_one_point_one) >= 0)
   10755             :     {
   10756        3372 :         local_rscale = rscale - x.weight * DEC_DIGITS / 2 + 8;
   10757        3372 :         sqrt_var(&x, &x, local_rscale);
   10758        3372 :         mul_var(&fact, &const_two, &fact, 0);
   10759        3372 :         nsqrt++;
   10760             :     }
   10761             : 
   10762             :     /*
   10763             :      * We use the Taylor series for 0.5 * ln((1+z)/(1-z)),
   10764             :      *
   10765             :      * z + z^3/3 + z^5/5 + ...
   10766             :      *
   10767             :      * where z = (x-1)/(x+1) is in the range (approximately) -0.053 .. 0.048
   10768             :      * due to the above range-reduction of x.
   10769             :      *
   10770             :      * The convergence of this is not as fast as one would like, but is
   10771             :      * tolerable given that z is small.
   10772             :      *
   10773             :      * The Taylor series result will be multiplied by 2^(nsqrt+1), which has a
   10774             :      * decimal weight of (nsqrt+1) * log10(2), so work with this many extra
   10775             :      * digits of precision (plus a few more for good measure).
   10776             :      */
   10777         756 :     local_rscale = rscale + (int) ((nsqrt + 1) * 0.301029995663981) + 8;
   10778             : 
   10779         756 :     sub_var(&x, &const_one, result);
   10780         756 :     add_var(&x, &const_one, &elem);
   10781         756 :     div_var_fast(result, &elem, result, local_rscale, true);
   10782         756 :     set_var_from_var(result, &xx);
   10783         756 :     mul_var(result, result, &x, local_rscale);
   10784             : 
   10785         756 :     ni = 1;
   10786             : 
   10787             :     for (;;)
   10788             :     {
   10789       14022 :         ni += 2;
   10790       14022 :         mul_var(&xx, &x, &xx, local_rscale);
   10791       14022 :         div_var_int(&xx, ni, 0, &elem, local_rscale, true);
   10792             : 
   10793       14022 :         if (elem.ndigits == 0)
   10794         756 :             break;
   10795             : 
   10796       13266 :         add_var(result, &elem, result);
   10797             : 
   10798       13266 :         if (elem.weight < (result->weight - local_rscale * 2 / DEC_DIGITS))
   10799           0 :             break;
   10800             :     }
   10801             : 
   10802             :     /* Compensate for argument range reduction, round to requested rscale */
   10803         756 :     mul_var(result, &fact, result, rscale);
   10804             : 
   10805         756 :     free_var(&x);
   10806         756 :     free_var(&xx);
   10807         756 :     free_var(&elem);
   10808         756 :     free_var(&fact);
   10809         756 : }
   10810             : 
   10811             : 
   10812             : /*
   10813             :  * log_var() -
   10814             :  *
   10815             :  *  Compute the logarithm of num in a given base.
   10816             :  *
   10817             :  *  Note: this routine chooses dscale of the result.
   10818             :  */
   10819             : static void
   10820         216 : log_var(const NumericVar *base, const NumericVar *num, NumericVar *result)
   10821             : {
   10822             :     NumericVar  ln_base;
   10823             :     NumericVar  ln_num;
   10824             :     int         ln_base_dweight;
   10825             :     int         ln_num_dweight;
   10826             :     int         result_dweight;
   10827             :     int         rscale;
   10828             :     int         ln_base_rscale;
   10829             :     int         ln_num_rscale;
   10830             : 
   10831         216 :     init_var(&ln_base);
   10832         216 :     init_var(&ln_num);
   10833             : 
   10834             :     /* Estimated dweights of ln(base), ln(num) and the final result */
   10835         216 :     ln_base_dweight = estimate_ln_dweight(base);
   10836         216 :     ln_num_dweight = estimate_ln_dweight(num);
   10837         216 :     result_dweight = ln_num_dweight - ln_base_dweight;
   10838             : 
   10839             :     /*
   10840             :      * Select the scale of the result so that it will have at least
   10841             :      * NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS significant digits and is not less than either
   10842             :      * input's display scale.
   10843             :      */
   10844         216 :     rscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS - result_dweight;
   10845         216 :     rscale = Max(rscale, base->dscale);
   10846         216 :     rscale = Max(rscale, num->dscale);
   10847         216 :     rscale = Max(rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10848         216 :     rscale = Min(rscale, NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10849             : 
   10850             :     /*
   10851             :      * Set the scales for ln(base) and ln(num) so that they each have more
   10852             :      * significant digits than the final result.
   10853             :      */
   10854         216 :     ln_base_rscale = rscale + result_dweight - ln_base_dweight + 8;
   10855         216 :     ln_base_rscale = Max(ln_base_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10856             : 
   10857         216 :     ln_num_rscale = rscale + result_dweight - ln_num_dweight + 8;
   10858         216 :     ln_num_rscale = Max(ln_num_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10859             : 
   10860             :     /* Form natural logarithms */
   10861         216 :     ln_var(base, &ln_base, ln_base_rscale);
   10862         192 :     ln_var(num, &ln_num, ln_num_rscale);
   10863             : 
   10864             :     /* Divide and round to the required scale */
   10865         162 :     div_var_fast(&ln_num, &ln_base, result, rscale, true);
   10866             : 
   10867         156 :     free_var(&ln_num);
   10868         156 :     free_var(&ln_base);
   10869         156 : }

   10872             : /*
   10873             :  * power_var() -
   10874             :  *
   10875             :  *  Raise base to the power of exp
   10876             :  *
   10877             :  *  Note: this routine chooses dscale of the result.
   10878             :  */
   10879             : static void
   10880        1140 : power_var(const NumericVar *base, const NumericVar *exp, NumericVar *result)
   10881             : {
   10882             :     int         res_sign;
   10883             :     NumericVar  abs_base;
   10884             :     NumericVar  ln_base;
   10885             :     NumericVar  ln_num;
   10886             :     int         ln_dweight;
   10887             :     int         rscale;
   10888             :     int         sig_digits;
   10889             :     int         local_rscale;
   10890             :     double      val;
   10891             : 
   10892             :     /* If exp can be represented as an integer, use power_var_int */
   10893        1140 :     if (exp->ndigits == 0 || exp->ndigits <= exp->weight + 1)
   10894             :     {
   10895             :         /* exact integer, but does it fit in int? */
   10896             :         int64       expval64;
   10897             : 
   10898        1014 :         if (numericvar_to_int64(exp, &expval64))
   10899             :         {
   10900        1008 :             if (expval64 >= PG_INT32_MIN && expval64 <= PG_INT32_MAX)
   10901             :             {
   10902             :                 /* Okay, use power_var_int */
   10903         978 :                 power_var_int(base, (int) expval64, exp->dscale, result);
   10904         966 :                 return;
   10905             :             }
   10906             :         }
   10907             :     }
   10908             : 
   10909             :     /*
   10910             :      * This avoids log(0) for cases of 0 raised to a non-integer.  0 ^ 0 is
   10911             :      * handled by power_var_int().
   10912             :      */
   10913         162 :     if (cmp_var(base, &const_zero) == 0)
   10914             :     {
   10915          18 :         set_var_from_var(&const_zero, result);
   10916          18 :         result->dscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS; /* no need to round */
   10917          18 :         return;
   10918             :     }
   10919             : 
   10920         144 :     init_var(&abs_base);
   10921         144 :     init_var(&ln_base);
   10922         144 :     init_var(&ln_num);
   10923             : 
   10924             :     /*
   10925             :      * If base is negative, insist that exp be an integer.  The result is then
   10926             :      * positive if exp is even and negative if exp is odd.
   10927             :      */
   10928         144 :     if (base->sign == NUMERIC_NEG)
   10929             :     {
   10930             :         /*
   10931             :          * Check that exp is an integer.  This error code is defined by the
   10932             :          * SQL standard, and matches other errors in numeric_power().
   10933             :          */
   10934          36 :         if (exp->ndigits > 0 && exp->ndigits > exp->weight + 1)
   10935          18 :             ereport(ERROR,
   10936             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_ARGUMENT_FOR_POWER_FUNCTION),
   10937             :                      errmsg("a negative number raised to a non-integer power yields a complex result")));
   10938             : 
   10939             :         /* Test if exp is odd or even */
   10940          18 :         if (exp->ndigits > 0 && exp->ndigits == exp->weight + 1 &&
   10941          12 :             (exp->digits[exp->ndigits - 1] & 1))
   10942           6 :             res_sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
   10943             :         else
   10944          12 :             res_sign = NUMERIC_POS;
   10945             : 
   10946             :         /* Then work with abs(base) below */
   10947          18 :         set_var_from_var(base, &abs_base);
   10948          18 :         abs_base.sign = NUMERIC_POS;
   10949          18 :         base = &abs_base;
   10950             :     }
   10951             :     else
   10952         108 :         res_sign = NUMERIC_POS;
   10953             : 
   10954             :     /*----------
   10955             :      * Decide on the scale for the ln() calculation.  For this we need an
   10956             :      * estimate of the weight of the result, which we obtain by doing an
   10957             :      * initial low-precision calculation of exp * ln(base).
   10958             :      *
   10959             :      * We want result = e ^ (exp * ln(base))
   10960             :      * so result dweight = log10(result) = exp * ln(base) * log10(e)
   10961             :      *
   10962             :      * We also perform a crude overflow test here so that we can exit early if
   10963             :      * the full-precision result is sure to overflow, and to guard against
   10964             :      * integer overflow when determining the scale for the real calculation.
   10965             :      * exp_var() supports inputs up to NUMERIC_MAX_RESULT_SCALE * 3, so the
   10966             :      * result will overflow if exp * ln(base) >= NUMERIC_MAX_RESULT_SCALE * 3.
   10967             :      * Since the values here are only approximations, we apply a small fuzz
   10968             :      * factor to this overflow test and let exp_var() determine the exact
   10969             :      * overflow threshold so that it is consistent for all inputs.
   10970             :      *----------
   10971             :      */
   10972         126 :     ln_dweight = estimate_ln_dweight(base);
   10973             : 
   10974             :     /*
   10975             :      * Set the scale for the low-precision calculation, computing ln(base) to
   10976             :      * around 8 significant digits.  Note that ln_dweight may be as small as
   10977             :      * -SHRT_MAX, so the scale may exceed NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE here.
   10978             :      */
   10979         126 :     local_rscale = 8 - ln_dweight;
   10980         126 :     local_rscale = Max(local_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   10981             : 
   10982         126 :     ln_var(base, &ln_base, local_rscale);
   10983             : 
   10984         126 :     mul_var(&ln_base, exp, &ln_num, local_rscale);
   10985             : 
   10986         126 :     val = numericvar_to_double_no_overflow(&ln_num);
   10987             : 
   10988             :     /* initial overflow/underflow test with fuzz factor */
   10989         126 :     if (fabs(val) > NUMERIC_MAX_RESULT_SCALE * 3.01)
   10990             :     {
   10991           6 :         if (val > 0)
   10992           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   10993             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_NUMERIC_VALUE_OUT_OF_RANGE),
   10994             :                      errmsg("value overflows numeric format")));
   10995           6 :         zero_var(result);
   10996           6 :         result->dscale = NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE;
   10997           6 :         return;
   10998             :     }
   10999             : 
   11000         120 :     val *= 0.434294481903252;   /* approximate decimal result weight */
   11001             : 
   11002             :     /* choose the result scale */
   11003         120 :     rscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS - (int) val;
   11004         120 :     rscale = Max(rscale, base->dscale);
   11005         120 :     rscale = Max(rscale, exp->dscale);
   11006         120 :     rscale = Max(rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11007         120 :     rscale = Min(rscale, NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11008             : 
   11009             :     /* significant digits required in the result */
   11010         120 :     sig_digits = rscale + (int) val;
   11011         120 :     sig_digits = Max(sig_digits, 0);
   11012             : 
   11013             :     /* set the scale for the real exp * ln(base) calculation */
   11014         120 :     local_rscale = sig_digits - ln_dweight + 8;
   11015         120 :     local_rscale = Max(local_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11016             : 
   11017             :     /* and do the real calculation */
   11018             : 
   11019         120 :     ln_var(base, &ln_base, local_rscale);
   11020             : 
   11021         120 :     mul_var(&ln_base, exp, &ln_num, local_rscale);
   11022             : 
   11023         120 :     exp_var(&ln_num, result, rscale);
   11024             : 
   11025         120 :     if (res_sign == NUMERIC_NEG && result->ndigits > 0)
   11026           6 :         result->sign = NUMERIC_NEG;
   11027             : 
   11028         120 :     free_var(&ln_num);
   11029         120 :     free_var(&ln_base);
   11030         120 :     free_var(&abs_base);
   11031             : }
   11032             : 
   11033             : /*
   11034             :  * power_var_int() -
   11035             :  *
   11036             :  *  Raise base to the power of exp, where exp is an integer.
   11037             :  *
   11038             :  *  Note: this routine chooses dscale of the result.
   11039             :  */
   11040             : static void
   11041         978 : power_var_int(const NumericVar *base, int exp, int exp_dscale,
   11042             :               NumericVar *result)
   11043             : {
   11044             :     double      f;
   11045             :     int         p;
   11046             :     int         i;
   11047             :     int         rscale;
   11048             :     int         sig_digits;
   11049             :     unsigned int mask;
   11050             :     bool        neg;
   11051             :     NumericVar  base_prod;
   11052             :     int         local_rscale;
   11053             : 
   11054             :     /*
   11055             :      * Choose the result scale.  For this we need an estimate of the decimal
   11056             :      * weight of the result, which we obtain by approximating using double
   11057             :      * precision arithmetic.
   11058             :      *
   11059             :      * We also perform crude overflow/underflow tests here so that we can exit
   11060             :      * early if the result is sure to overflow/underflow, and to guard against
   11061             :      * integer overflow when choosing the result scale.
   11062             :      */
   11063         978 :     if (base->ndigits != 0)
   11064             :     {
   11065             :         /*----------
   11066             :          * Choose f (double) and p (int) such that base ~= f * 10^p.
   11067             :          * Then log10(result) = log10(base^exp) ~= exp * (log10(f) + p).
   11068             :          *----------
   11069             :          */
   11070         948 :         f = base->digits[0];
   11071         948 :         p = base->weight * DEC_DIGITS;
   11072             : 
   11073        1032 :         for (i = 1; i < base->ndigits && i * DEC_DIGITS < 16; i++)
   11074             :         {
   11075          84 :             f = f * NBASE + base->digits[i];
   11076          84 :             p -= DEC_DIGITS;
   11077             :         }
   11078             : 
   11079         948 :         f = exp * (log10(f) + p);   /* approximate decimal result weight */
   11080             :     }
   11081             :     else
   11082          30 :         f = 0;                  /* result is 0 or 1 (weight 0), or error */
   11083             : 
   11084             :     /* overflow/underflow tests with fuzz factors */
   11085         978 :     if (f > (SHRT_MAX + 1) * DEC_DIGITS)
   11086          12 :         ereport(ERROR,
   11087             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_NUMERIC_VALUE_OUT_OF_RANGE),
   11088             :                  errmsg("value overflows numeric format")));
   11089         966 :     if (f + 1 < -NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE)
   11090             :     {
   11091          12 :         zero_var(result);
   11092          12 :         result->dscale = NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE;
   11093         186 :         return;
   11094             :     }
   11095             : 
   11096             :     /*
   11097             :      * Choose the result scale in the same way as power_var(), so it has at
   11098             :      * least NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS significant digits and is not less than
   11099             :      * either input's display scale.
   11100             :      */
   11101         954 :     rscale = NUMERIC_MIN_SIG_DIGITS - (int) f;
   11102         954 :     rscale = Max(rscale, base->dscale);
   11103         954 :     rscale = Max(rscale, exp_dscale);
   11104         954 :     rscale = Max(rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11105         954 :     rscale = Min(rscale, NUMERIC_MAX_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11106             : 
   11107             :     /* Handle some common special cases, as well as corner cases */
   11108         954 :     switch (exp)
   11109             :     {
   11110          66 :         case 0:
   11111             : 
   11112             :             /*
   11113             :              * While 0 ^ 0 can be either 1 or indeterminate (error), we treat
   11114             :              * it as 1 because most programming languages do this. SQL:2003
   11115             :              * also requires a return value of 1.
   11116             :              * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentiation#Zero_to_the_zero_power
   11117             :              */
   11118          66 :             set_var_from_var(&const_one, result);
   11119          66 :             result->dscale = rscale; /* no need to round */
   11120          66 :             return;
   11121          42 :         case 1:
   11122          42 :             set_var_from_var(base, result);
   11123          42 :             round_var(result, rscale);
   11124          42 :             return;
   11125          24 :         case -1:
   11126          24 :             div_var(&const_one, base, result, rscale, true);
   11127          24 :             return;
   11128          42 :         case 2:
   11129          42 :             mul_var(base, base, result, rscale);
   11130          42 :             return;
   11131         780 :         default:
   11132         780 :             break;
   11133             :     }
   11134             : 
   11135             :     /* Handle the special case where the base is zero */
   11136         780 :     if (base->ndigits == 0)
   11137             :     {
   11138           0 :         if (exp < 0)
   11139           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
   11140             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DIVISION_BY_ZERO),
   11141             :                      errmsg("division by zero")));
   11142           0 :         zero_var(result);
   11143           0 :         result->dscale = rscale;
   11144           0 :         return;
   11145             :     }
   11146             : 
   11147             :     /*
   11148             :      * The general case repeatedly multiplies base according to the bit
   11149             :      * pattern of exp.
   11150             :      *
   11151             :      * The local rscale used for each multiplication is varied to keep a fixed
   11152             :      * number of significant digits, sufficient to give the required result
   11153             :      * scale.
   11154             :      */
   11155             : 
   11156             :     /*
   11157             :      * Approximate number of significant digits in the result.  Note that the
   11158             :      * underflow test above, together with the choice of rscale, ensures that
   11159             :      * this approximation is necessarily > 0.
   11160             :      */
   11161         780 :     sig_digits = 1 + rscale + (int) f;
   11162             : 
   11163             :     /*
   11164             :      * The multiplications to produce the result may introduce an error of up
   11165             :      * to around log10(abs(exp)) digits, so work with this many extra digits
   11166             :      * of precision (plus a few more for good measure).
   11167             :      */
   11168         780 :     sig_digits += (int) log(fabs((double) exp)) + 8;
   11169             : 
   11170             :     /*
   11171             :      * Now we can proceed with the multiplications.
   11172             :      */
   11173         780 :     neg = (exp < 0);
   11174         780 :     mask = abs(exp);
   11175             : 
   11176         780 :     init_var(&base_prod);
   11177         780 :     set_var_from_var(base, &base_prod);
   11178             : 
   11179         780 :     if (mask & 1)
   11180         390 :         set_var_from_var(base, result);
   11181             :     else
   11182         390 :         set_var_from_var(&const_one, result);
   11183             : 
   11184        4200 :     while ((mask >>= 1) > 0)
   11185             :     {
   11186             :         /*
   11187             :          * Do the multiplications using rscales large enough to hold the
   11188             :          * results to the required number of significant digits, but don't
   11189             :          * waste time by exceeding the scales of the numbers themselves.
   11190             :          */
   11191        3420 :         local_rscale = sig_digits - 2 * base_prod.weight * DEC_DIGITS;
   11192        3420 :         local_rscale = Min(local_rscale, 2 * base_prod.dscale);
   11193        3420 :         local_rscale = Max(local_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11194             : 
   11195        3420 :         mul_var(&base_prod, &base_prod, &base_prod, local_rscale);
   11196             : 
   11197        3420 :         if (mask & 1)
   11198             :         {
   11199        2274 :             local_rscale = sig_digits -
   11200        2274 :                 (base_prod.weight + result->weight) * DEC_DIGITS;
   11201        2274 :             local_rscale = Min(local_rscale,
   11202             :                                base_prod.dscale + result->dscale);
   11203        2274 :             local_rscale = Max(local_rscale, NUMERIC_MIN_DISPLAY_SCALE);
   11204             : 
   11205        2274 :             mul_var(&base_prod, result, result, local_rscale);
   11206             :         }
   11207             : 
   11208             :         /*
   11209             :          * When abs(base) > 1, the number of digits to the left of the decimal
   11210             :          * point in base_prod doubles at each iteration, so if exp is large we
   11211             :          * could easily spend large amounts of time and memory space doing the
   11212             :          * multiplications.  But once the weight exceeds what will fit in
   11213             :          * int16, the final result is guaranteed to overflow (or underflow, if
   11214             :          * exp < 0), so we can give up before wasting too many cycles.
   11215             :          */
   11216        3420 :         if (base_prod.weight > SHRT_MAX || result->weight > SHRT_MAX)

   11218             :             /* overflow, unless neg, in which case result should be 0 */
   11219           0 :             if (!neg)
   11220           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   11221             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_NUMERIC_VALUE_OUT_OF_RANGE),
   11222             :                          errmsg("value overflows numeric format")));
   11223           0 :             zero_var(result);
   11224           0 :             neg = false;
   11225           0 :             break;
   11226             :         }
   11227             :     }
   11228             : 
   11229         780 :     free_var(&base_prod);
   11230             : 
   11231             :     /* Compensate for input sign, and round to requested rscale */
   11232         780 :     if (neg)
   11233         366 :         div_var_fast(&const_one, result, result, rscale, true);

   11238             : /*
   11239             :  * power_ten_int() -
   11240             :  *
   11241             :  *  Raise ten to the power of exp, where exp is an integer.  Note that unlike
   11242             :  *  power_var_int(), this does no overflow/underflow checking or rounding.
   11243             :  */
   11244             : static void
   11245         216 : power_ten_int(int exp, NumericVar *result)
   11246             : {
   11247             :     /* Construct the result directly, starting from 10^0 = 1 */
   11248         216 :     set_var_from_var(&const_one, result);

   11250             :     /* Scale needed to represent the result exactly */
   11251         216 :     result->dscale = exp < 0 ? -exp : 0;
   11252             : 
   11253             :     /* Base-NBASE weight of result and remaining exponent */
   11254         216 :     if (exp >= 0)
   11255         150 :         result->weight = exp / DEC_DIGITS;
   11256             :     else
   11257          66 :         result->weight = (exp + 1) / DEC_DIGITS - 1;
   11258             : 
   11259         216 :     exp -= result->weight * DEC_DIGITS;
   11260             : 
   11261             :     /* Final adjustment of the result's single NBASE digit */
   11262         546 :     while (exp-- > 0)
   11263         330 :         result->digits[0] *= 10;

   11405             :     {

   11439             : /*
   11440             :  * sub_abs()
   11441             :  *
   11442             :  *  Subtract the absolute value of var2 from the absolute value of var1
   11443             :  *  and store in result. result might point to one of the operands
   11444             :  *  without danger.
   11445             :  *
   11446             :  *  ABS(var1) MUST BE GREATER OR EQUAL ABS(var2) !!!

   11523             : /*
   11524             :  * round_var
   11525             :  *
   11526             :  * Round the value of a variable to no more than rscale decimal digits
   11527             :  * after the decimal point.  NOTE: we allow rscale < 0 here, implying
   11528             :  * rounding before the decimal point.
   11529             :  */

   11531      997982 : round_var(NumericVar *var, int rscale)

   11752             : /*
   11753             :  * Accumulate a new value.
   11754             :  */
   11755             : static void
   11756     2355716 : accum_sum_add(NumericSumAccum *accum, const NumericVar *val)
   11757             : {
   11758             :     int32      *accum_digits;

   11760             :                 val_i;
   11761             :     int         val_ndigits;
   11762             :     NumericDigit *val_digits;
   11763             : 
   11764             :     /*
   11765             :      * If we have accumulated too many values since the last carry
   11766             :      * propagation, do it now, to avoid overflowing.  (We could allow more
   11767             :      * than NBASE - 1, if we reserved two extra digits, rather than one, for
   11768             :      * carry propagation.  But even with NBASE - 1, this needs to be done so
   11769             :      * seldom, that the performance difference is negligible.)
   11770             :      */

   11799             : 
   11800             : /*
   11801             :  * Propagate carries.
   11802             :  */
   11803             : static void
   11804      172776 : accum_sum_carry(NumericSumAccum *accum)
   11805             : {
   11806             :     int         i;
   11807             :     int         ndigits;
   11808             :     int32      *dig;
   11809             :     int32       carry;
   11810      172776 :     int32       newdig = 0;
   11811             : 
   11812             :     /*
   11813             :      * If no new values have been added since last carry propagation, nothing
   11814             :      * to do.
   11815             :      */
   11816      172776 :     if (accum->num_uncarried == 0)
   11817          72 :         return;
   11818             : 
   11819             :     /*
   11820             :      * We maintain that the weight of the accumulator is always one larger
   11821             :      * than needed to hold the current value, before carrying, to make sure
   11822             :      * there is enough space for the possible extra digit when carry is
   11823             :      * propagated.  We cannot expand the buffer here, unless we require
   11824             :      * callers of accum_sum_final() to switch to the right memory context.
   11825             :      */
   11826      172704 :     Assert(accum->pos_digits[0] == 0 && accum->neg_digits[0] == 0);
   11827             : 
   11828      172704 :     ndigits = accum->ndigits;

   11830             :     /* Propagate carry in the positive sum */
   11831      172704 :     dig = accum->pos_digits;

   11833     2605596 :     for (i = ndigits - 1; i >= 0; i--)

   11836     2432892 :         if (newdig >= NBASE)

   11841             :         else
   11842     2322094 :             carry = 0;

   11844             :     }

   11847        2640 :         accum->have_carry_space = false;
   11848             : 
   11849             :     /* And the same for the negative sum */
   11850      172704 :     dig = accum->neg_digits;
   11851      172704 :     carry = 0;
   11852     2605596 :     for (i = ndigits - 1; i >= 0; i--)
   11853             :     {
   11854     2432892 :         newdig = dig[i] + carry;
   11855     2432892 :         if (newdig >= NBASE)
   11856             :         {
   11857         198 :             carry = newdig / NBASE;
   11858         198 :             newdig -= carry * NBASE;
   11859             :         }
   11860             :         else
   11861     2432694 :             carry = 0;
   11862     2432892 :         dig[i] = newdig;
   11863             :     }

   11866             : 
   11867      172704 :     accum->num_uncarried = 0;

   11869             : 
   11870             : /*
   11871             :  * Re-scale accumulator to accommodate new value.
   11872             :  *
   11873             :  * If the new value has more digits than the current digit buffers in the
   11874             :  * accumulator, enlarge the buffers.
   11875             :  */
   11876             : static void
   11877     2355716 : accum_sum_rescale(NumericSumAccum *accum, const NumericVar *val)
   11878             : {
   11879     2355716 :     int         old_weight = accum->weight;
   11880     2355716 :     int         old_ndigits = accum->ndigits;
   11881             :     int         accum_ndigits;
   11882             :     int         accum_weight;
   11883             :     int         accum_rscale;
   11884             :     int         val_rscale;
   11885             : 
   11886     2355716 :     accum_weight = old_weight;
   11887     2355716 :     accum_ndigits = old_ndigits;
   11888             : 
   11889             :     /*
   11890             :      * Does the new value have a larger weight? If so, enlarge the buffers,
   11891             :      * and shift the existing value to the new weight, by adding leading
   11892             :      * zeros.
   11893             :      *
   11894             :      * We enforce that the accumulator always has a weight one larger than
   11895             :      * needed for the inputs, so that we have space for an extra digit at the
   11896             :      * final carry-propagation phase, if necessary.
   11897             :      */
   11898     2355716 :     if (val->weight >= accum_weight)
   11899             :     {
   11900      262236 :         accum_weight = val->weight + 1;
   11901      262236 :         accum_ndigits = accum_ndigits + (accum_weight - old_weight);
   11902             :     }
   11903             : 
   11904             :     /*
   11905             :      * Even though the new value is small, we might've used up the space
   11906             :      * reserved for the carry digit in the last call to accum_sum_carry().  If
   11907             :      * so, enlarge to make room for another one.
   11908             :      */
   11909     2093480 :     else if (!accum->have_carry_space)
   11910             :     {
   11911          90 :         accum_weight++;
   11912          90 :         accum_ndigits++;
   11913             :     }
   11914             : 
   11915             :     /* Is the new value wider on the right side? */
   11916     2355716 :     accum_rscale = accum_ndigits - accum_weight - 1;
   11917     2355716 :     val_rscale = val->ndigits - val->weight - 1;
   11918     2355716 :     if (val_rscale > accum_rscale)
   11919      172258 :         accum_ndigits = accum_ndigits + (val_rscale - accum_rscale);
   11920             : 
   11921     2355716 :     if (accum_ndigits != old_ndigits ||
   11922             :         accum_weight != old_weight)
   11923             :     {
   11924             :         int32      *new_pos_digits;
   11925             :         int32      *new_neg_digits;
   11926             :         int         weightdiff;
   11927             : 
   11928      262622 :         weightdiff = accum_weight - old_weight;
   11929             : 
   11930      262622 :         new_pos_digits = palloc0(accum_ndigits * sizeof(int32));
   11931      262622 :         new_neg_digits = palloc0(accum_ndigits * sizeof(int32));
   11932             : 
   11933      262622 :         if (accum->pos_digits)
   11934             :         {
   11935       90434 :             memcpy(&new_pos_digits[weightdiff], accum->pos_digits,
   11936             :                    old_ndigits * sizeof(int32));
   11937       90434 :             pfree(accum->pos_digits);
   11938             : 
   11939       90434 :             memcpy(&new_neg_digits[weightdiff], accum->neg_digits,
   11940             :                    old_ndigits * sizeof(int32));
   11941       90434 :             pfree(accum->neg_digits);
   11942             :         }
   11943             : 
   11944      262622 :         accum->pos_digits = new_pos_digits;
   11945      262622 :         accum->neg_digits = new_neg_digits;
   11946             : 
   11947      262622 :         accum->weight = accum_weight;
   11948      262622 :         accum->ndigits = accum_ndigits;
   11949             :

   11958             : /*
   11959             :  * Return the current value of the accumulator.  This perform final carry
   11960             :  * propagation, and adds together the positive and negative sums.
   11961             :  *
   11962             :  * Unlike all the other routines, the caller is not required to switch to
   11963             :  * the memory context that holds the accumulator.
   11964             :  */

   12010             : /*
   12011             :  * Copy an accumulator's state.
   12012             :  *
   12013             :  * 'dst' is assumed to be uninitialized beforehand.  No attempt is made at
   12014             :  * freeing old values.
